It's a good action game, a little rough in spots, like areas where the BGM doesn't loop cleanly, but it's all minor nuisances really.

It consists of a simple gameplay-loop, you go into a location, which will consist of some 5 to 10 screens, you fight your way through some 4 or 5 different enemies (unique to said area), you unlock all the items available in that area, there's a boss fight, the story progresses, and then you go into a new location.

Combat is very fast and responsive,  not so intricate, you have a few different moves, but you couple regular melee attacks with powerful magical attacks/buffs  (that are activated by entering directional commands, kinda like a fighting game but not quite)

Progression is multi-faceted:
- you have your regular leveling system, just gaining exp from defeating  enemies, then distributing your points in different stats

- there's what the game calls the "grow system" which is this huge tree of, mostly, minor stat bonuses, that you get by spending a type of energy you get from defeating enemies, there are 6 different types of said energy, and you'll need a balance of them all (different enemies give off different types) to complete the whole tree, you can also get new magic skills and improve said skills in this same tree

- The game has MANY pieces of equipment, and each  has it's own progression of sorts, in which, while wearing/wielding an item, all experience you gain by killing enemies goes towards said item "mastery", when mastering an item you gain a new ability OR a crystal used to activate said abilities (it's a basic balancing system, for example, you have 8 crystals, and 10 abilities to chose from, some abilities need 3 crystals, some 4, some 1, and you have to decide which ones to enable)

And it's all very satisfying

I also like how the game respects the player's time, for instance you can respec every time you level up, or at any time in specific locations, plus you don't have to worry about missing any content since, after a certain point in the story progression, you can revisit any previous area to get anything you might have missed.

The story is your usual anime-grade nonsensical stuff, but it's alright

This is easily a 10/10 game for me. It's very rare to see so much love and care put into a game. 

Pros (story): 
- The execution of the story is extremely well-done, which is very important for any story that uses time travel as a plot device. 
- All of the characters that stick with the protagonist get development and receive whole story arcs that overlap with each other, complete with their own charm.
- The romance in the game is very sweet while remaining in the realm of believability.
- Supporting characters are remembered throughout the story, forming both a tight setting and a tight narrative.
- The main scenario is very long and is always doing something to keep the experience interesting.

Cons (story):
- Without spoilers, some presentation issues with Chapter 4 exist.
- There are scenarios in the game that are resolved in ways that may initially seem like too much of a stretch.

Notes (story):
- There are not that many choices for players to make during the plot, but it's highly recommended to save the game often and to use multiple save slots and the few choices that the player does get have dramatic effects.

/

Pros (gameplay):
- While not a truly a Metroidvania, many of the positive elements of exploration and combat encounters with common enemies lead to a very charming sidescrolling action RPG experience.
- Contains a unique Mastery system for weapons, shields, and armor; When gear is mastered, bonuses including new skills are added.
- Interactions between stats and skill modifiers are easy to understand 
- Every boss enemy in the game feels fair assuming the player understands every property of Possession Skills usage.
- There are no stat restrictions for any weapon, sub-weapon, or skill in the game.
- Extreme degree of enemy variety.
- High weapon variety including unique movesets for some weapons.
- Unlockable movement and attack techniques that are usable on any  gear set-up.
- Food is an important component to gameplay in a way that's both silly but effective.
- The Grow Tree system, while difficult to navigate, is a unique idea that works well within the game. It also provides an amusing bonus visual that becomes more apparent as one progresses through it.

Cons (gameplay):
- There are issues with hitbox size and active hitbox frames when it comes to some enemy attacks. 
- Player's input in combat can feel "spammy" due to the nature of the Gain/Spend dynamic. 
- The Libra system, while very impactful to the player's power, can be very time-consuming. 
- While there is no explicit sexual content, there is sexualized imagery that some players may find off-putting.

Astlibra is a fantastic Metroidvania with surprisingly good combat mechanics. This game is absolutely what you're looking for if you want to play something like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. The story can get surprisingly dark and mysterious which makes it very compelling.

The game also features a game mechanic where your companion learns passive skills from the equipment that you find from your journey (Weapons, Shields, and Armor). Enemies drop elemental "force" that you can use to give stat buffs to your character, unlock new offensive magical spells, and treasures to gain more power for your character (advancement of this mechanic is restricted at certain points until you further advance the story).

There is also a passive system that uses the items that you find and craft on your adventure to empower your character and offer unique benefits to your character such as increased resistance to all manner of status effects, increased exp, increased coins from enemies, and even passive Health recovery.

Many treasures are well hidden, and side content like the Arena offer fantastic rewards. The story is linear, but at certain points you are able to backtrack to seek missing treasure or additional force to power up your character. There is content in the game that you can miss depending on your decisions at certain points in the story.

I spent quite a bit of time on this game and it was very enjoyable. I honestly did a bit more grinding than I needed to when I could have just used a different setup to defeat a certain boss. Mix up your tactics and try different weapons as wildly swinging your weapon may not be enough to overcome your enemies.

The sound quality can be off at times as some enemies make strange sounds, but this game's soundtrack is quite fantastic. Visual quality is also very good overall. Be wary that some bosses fire many projectiles and you can lose track of what's going on if you have additional characters on screen when using your character's abilities. I would also strongly advise that you reduce the screen flashing in the options menu.

Overall this game is easy to recommend for anyone wanting a Metroidvania with a lot of content. It will keep you busy for quite some time and challenge you as much as you wish.

149126744.review:
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Love is an incredible force, isn't it? It can assume many shapes and comes from various places. Yet, there's something uniquely magical when love takes the form of creative passion, an art. This particular form of love is something that can be cherished by many. Astlibra: Revision represents the digital embodiment of one creator's affection. So, what fuels this game's essence? This review seeks to provide some insights.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]


To begin with, Astlibra's primary measure of progress revolves around numbers. This balance leans more towards a player's character skills than their skill and reflexes. For someone like me, who isn't particularly skilled at reflex-based games, this approach is favorable.

The progression system consists of several layers. The most straightforward is the level-up screen.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065178799

Next is the "grow board," where you can accumulate force points of different elements and use them to purchase stat upgrades. This is also where you unlock various spells, a topic I'll delve into later.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065179817

Throughout your journey, you'll amass a vast array of weapons, shields, armor, and accessories, each impacting your gameplay differently. There are swift weapons to pair with shields, though their reach is limited, and slow but potent two-handed weapons with extended range. Additionally, magic staves serve as projectile weapons, firing elemental projectiles.

Players acquire equipment by crafting with materials and blueprints dropped by monsters. The game cleverly encourages experimentation with various gears. Equipping them allows you to gain experience, and maxing them unlocks passive skills or yields magic crystals to slot your passive skills. However, one downside is that you won't know the skills acquired until you've maxed out the experience, necessitating trial and error in crafting and equipment selection.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065180877

Lastly, the game boasts a variety of magic spells, each aligned with one of six elements and spanning different tiers. Progression is well-paced, with new tiers of magic introduced in each chapter, ensuring the game remains engaging. On harder difficulties, it can become somewhat grindy, as acquiring as many passive skills and stat improvements as possible is crucial. Given the emphasis on numbers, the game allows for some forgiveness in terms of player clumsiness, depending on your build and system understanding. Players with better reflexes may have a different experience.

One occasional issue, particularly in later game sections, is visibility. As you advance, enemies unleash more potent attacks that can occasionally clutter the screen.

[b]But Wait, There’s More[/b]

Beyond the main storyline, the game offers a "postscript" chapter after Chapter 8, lasting an additional 10-20 hours. This segment is a crucial continuation of the story, introducing further progression elements in the form of weapon enhancement and the board mechanic. In postscript, all weapons, including starter ones, can be enhanced up to +99 using ingredients dropped by monsters.

Boards are also dropped by monsters and can be attached to specific equipment. Acquiring boards is somewhat RNG-dependent, as you can't predict when the right board for your specific equipment will drop. However, when obtained, the attached equipment's stats see a major boost. Some boards also contain upgrades for your existing passive and active skills. This evolution leads to earlier, less impactful spells becoming powerful tools in your arsenal. That weak fire bolt early evolved into a fast shooting bolt that explodes on impact and end-tier skills become a boss shredder on their own. 

One drawback of the postscript is that you'll revisit most of the same dungeons as in the main game, with the same inhabitant that's stronger. It's only at the very end that you encounter a new dungeon and set of bosses. Nevertheless, by this point, the story's  multiple twists, turns and long-awaited revelations keep you engaged.

[h1]Story[/h1]

The game commences with a familiar JRPG trope: the protagonist's hometown is besieged by demons, setting the stage for an epic battle against the demon king. However, Astlibra consistently hints at a more intricate narrative beneath the surface. While the story may appear slow at the outset, it gradually evolves into something unexpected and captivating. This subversion of traditional plot elements extends to the characters you encounter and recruit, endearing them to you as comrades.

What lags behind in the JRPG genre cliche are the lines of dialogue. They seem to strive for depth but often come across as a rough translation of generic JRPG conversations. While it doesn't significantly impact the overall plot, it leaves room for improvement in terms of editing and translation.

The most noticeable residue of generic JRPG writing is the use of eroticism as humor, which often falls flat and feels juvenile. It seems as if the game is attempting to resurrect the cringeworthy aspects of teenage humor. While dirty jokes can be effective when skillfully employed, Astlibra misses the mark. For instance, the humor in peeking at female party members in a hot spring ceased to be funny for me over a decade ago. The jarring aspect here is that the writer, while clearly amateur, effectively engages players' emotions and investments in the world and characters. When the storytelling is sincere and heartfelt, it fosters a deep connection to the game's universe.

[h1]Technical Issues and Bugs[/h1]
[u]Specs: RTX 3080, Ryzen 3700x, 16GB RAM, 1440p[/u]

The game maintains a consistent level of polish from start to finish. While it's not without some rough edges, I encountered no issues that hindered my overall enjoyment.

[h1]Graphics and Visual[/h1]

Astlibra's graphics appear to be stitched together from diverse assets created by different artists. Some areas, especially in the early game and the main hub, look somewhat rough. However, the game manages to establish a unique aesthetic that's unmistakably Astlibra. At the very least, the blocky terrain and square caves and mountains serve their utilitarian purpose. Occasionally, when everything aligns just right, the backgrounds can be visually stunning.

Credit is due to the developer for enlisting the talents of Shigatake, the character designer from Vanillaware, to enhance the portraits and sprites of various characters. The visibility of equipped gear also contributes to the game's coolness factor.

[h1]Audio and Music[/h1]

The game boasts over 130 tracks sourced from various origins, both free and paid. Surprisingly, they blend seamlessly within the game, with some tracks being particularly impressive. Given the sheer number of tracks, each locale, dungeon, and boss fight has its own unique theme that complements the mood perfectly. On the other hand, the sound effects serve a utilitarian role, indicating the success of a block, a successful hit, and telegraphing enemy attacks.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Astlibra is a labor of love crafted by developer KEIZO, a project spanning 14 years. This dedication and struggle are evident in the game's creation. Like homemade cookies from a dearly beloved, it may be a bit uneven and blemished in places, but it's something you can wholeheartedly enjoy. Astlibra is a form of art that resonated with me at the right time, and I'm likely to fondly remember it for the rest of my life.

A game with an Overwhelmingly Positive rating and everyone dropping GOTY comments and some people saying it's on par with Zelda TotK. That's HIGH PRAISE. I've had this sitting in my library for a while and decided to finally boot it up. I wish I had played this last year! It's easily going to go down as one of the best indie games I've ever played.

The story is phenomenally well written, but I HIGHLY suggest playing the demo first, as there's a story element you get from it that gives context to the actual start of the game that I think without it, the prison world the protagonist is in is more confusing. I have been super engrossed in this character's plight to release themselves from this consciousness prison they found themselves in and it gives huge Matrix vibes.

The combat is just downright genius. It's super fast paced and still quite simple, but the genius lies in the gear mastery system. There's an insane number of weapons, armor, and shields you have to master in order to gain a permanent upgrade to your character. This means you're constantly changing out your gear and trying new builds. It keeps things feeling immensely refreshed and the differences between the gear make subtle changes to how you have to approach combat. I love this and wish Dark Souls games used this system.

Boss battles are absolutely magnificent, right from the get go. You jump right into battles with gods, dragons, and mega demons, instead of having to face small-time bosses. The game makes you think it's going to be that way though, before completely subverting your expectations. The designer of this game really understands that players want COOL experiences and they sure as heck deliver.

I actually find the graphics quite appealing. They're kind of painterly and surreal. I honestly have been surprised because screenshots really don't do it justice. Places like the main town you get to are quite beautiful and well designed.

I cannot understate how incredible this game is. I know it has like 20,000 reviews, but this seriously has to be one of the biggest sleeper games of all time, if not the #1. Anyone who's had the opportunity to play this game should consider themselves lucky. It's a pristine gem.

One of the very few games I've unlocked all achievements for, Astlibra is now one of my all time Action RPG favorites, up there with some of the Ys games.

This game is a labor of love and effort, made single handedly by a japanese salaryman who decided to make a game to relax after work by grinding mobs for gear, and afterwards, gave it a narrative and shared it to the world as a Freeware title. Astlibra Revision is a revamped version of said game, worth every penny.

Although graphically offputting at first, the polish of the game is felt through every fast paced action you take. The music, although from a free sound library, is simply amazing and well-picked for each moment of the game, and the ammount of content, including side quests, secret bosses and dungeons, rivals some of the classics.

Gameplay is essentialy a 2D Action platformer moreso than a Metroidvania, although some exploration and backtracking is expected for secrets and completion. You level up and invest resources to upgrade your weapons and skills, and your equipment also gains experience, which in turn lets you learn the abilities that otherwise you can only use while keeping it equiped.

The story is also quite good. The writing isn't stellar and can be quite tropey, full of classic anime tropes and lewdness here and there, but it's also good and sentimental enough for you to want to keep playing just to see what happens next, with stakes upping during the mid and final portions of the game.

On the negative side, it has some jank and occasional bugs, but nothing game breaking. Menus can be clunky to use, and the aftermentioned fanservice/lewdness can get in the way and create some awkward moments, but none of this detracts from the amazing experience Astlibra gives.

145868580.review:
Old school hack and slash that perfectly blends:

* Combo smashing: Combo goes brrr, yet you don't even have to spam since there is a skill that let you hold a button and your character will just execute the combo automatically. What matter is timing and mixing up your attack.
* Timed blocking: You have a shield, use it. Even bosses' attacks can be blocked perfectly. But being passive and hiding behind your shield means becoming a sitting duck. Your stamina is limited. You can't keep blocking indefinitely.
* Special attack: Normal attack fills up a gauge that can be used for a wide range of special attacks with devastating damage.
   It starts with holding a button, inputting a fighting game style sequence of directional keys (e.g: down up) and releasing the previous button.
   You would summon and sometimes transform into Final Fantasy style GF spirits.
   They also grant you a short period of invincibility.
   The best defense is a well timed offense.
   You can negate a bunch of hard to dodge, costly to block attacks by a timely special.
   Which brings us to:
* Counter attack. Block an attack and immediately counter also grant you invincibility frames.
   This is a key to get through some seemingly impenetrable defenses.
   It feels amazing to execute that perfect sequence of blocking, counter attack then special, throwing a bunch of numbers up while dashing through a flurry of threats being thrown at you.

Not only that, the battle system is supported by:

* A host of varied craftable weapons and equipment each with their own play style.
* Weapon mastery can give you a bunch of useful passive skills.
* A skill tree system that looks more like a skill maze.

It may sound like there is a lot of grinding but there isn't.
Even on hell difficulty (the second highest), I never had to grind.
Just exploring, walking from one objective point to other, killing everything on the way is enough to get through the game.
Not just that, before boss fights, the game always let you respec your stats for **free** so you can tinker with your build to find the best way to tackle a boss battle.
You are never trapped in an invalid build, making you grind to make up for it.
There are respec potions but I never had to use them since the game is so generous with respec points.

Also, the mixtape (music) is fire. Even in the beginning when you only have a tree branch to hit some slime, the music goes hard.
It makes me want to be a JRPG heroes and save them waifus.

Cons:

* The dialogue is kinda silly. Jokes are sometimes made in serious scenes that just breaks the mood and then characters went serious again.
* The story is pretty cliched so far. A do gooder, self sacrificing hero with insane strength (you) trying to save everyone with the power of friendship.

If you do play, I recommend starting with Hell and lower it to Hard if it's too challenging or your progression is too slow.
At certain point in the game, you can't raise it up to Hell again.
On hard, the game is moderately challenging, you do die often if you are careless.
In difficulty below Hell (second highest), the game pauses when you are inputting your fighting game style button sequence for your special attack. It makes timing a lot easier and forgiving.
In Hell and above, there are no more pauses. You have to perfectly master those timings. It feels good to do the same damage cancelling sequence said above in real time, dodging death by a hairline.
However, I admit I'm getting old and my progression in Hell is too slow since I have to keep retrying the same path and bosses.
I dropped to Hard later and the game is enjoyable so far.

145354051.review:
Goodness, how bizarre. ASTLIBRA Revision is one of the most unique games I've played in recent memory. It is a strange frankenstein of a game that manages to be so much more than the sum of its parts. It's paradoxical, a game which uses assets from countless sources strongly coalesces them into its own artistic style. Royalty free music, assets that I've certainly seen in RPGMaker games, the game is stitched together from a thousand different places. I feel a strange nostalgia for this, as though it was a browser game from an online ecosystem which hasn't existed since the early 2010s. In that sense it's almost a period piece, but I digress. 

I see a lot of praise for the story, yet it's similarly chimeric, for better and for worse. On the surface, it's a large pot of generic Anime Fantasy tropes; an adventurer's guild, a demon king, a nameless self-insert protagonist, (and a lot of crossdressing). Some people may not have the same level of tolerance for that sort of thing, but if you're seriously considering a game that looks like this from the outset, you've probably got that under control. All of this belies the fact that the story is well-paced; Almost episodic in nature, yet with each chapter effectively building towards successively larger climaxes and reveals. Tropes are tools, and even if the fantasy anime toolbox is well-worn at this point, this story uses them better than I could ask for. 

As for the gameplay, it's quite solid and straightforward, once one understands the meaning behind each of the menus. There's about 4 and a half systems for improving your character, but there's really only one style of gameplay- sword, shield, and the occassional spell. 'Action-RPG' is a nebulously defined genre, but this feels like the platonic ideal of it; Combat's fast-paced and relatively snappy, yet the character building is consequential. Aside from that, everything else is pretty self-expanatory. (Thank goodness for that, this game's only wiki is in Japanese.)

I cannot stop thinking about this game. Even months later, I feel the need to know more about it, the story behind it and surrounding it. I'll definitely be returning for a hard-mode playthrough, once I get the chance.

Tldr: I bought this game based on the overwhelmingly positive reviews. I understood from the footage this was a low $ type of game but the encouragement from the positive reviews made me think there was good combat and a different and interesting story. What I found was frustrating gameplay (combat) and only a mediocre story that for me, was pretty slow to unfold and had some pretty readable twists (although one I was not expecting in chpt 4). After lots of frustration with the combat, frustration with lack of info in game about how to proceed in certain areas (i.e. you need to unlock an invincible jump move prior to progressing at one point) and lack of any character connection with the story or really more than just passing interest in what was going to happen next, I gave up. I believe a lot of the positive reviews stem from people desperate from an old-school ARPG in the vein of Castlevania (although this one has a different combat than that and made me think of Trails of series from all the gemstone explosions in loot). If you want something janky that scratches that itch, then I guess this game may be up your alley but for me I can't recommend.

Gameplay: This is a combat-focused game interspersed with narrative scenes. You will be platforming (which I didn't care for in this setting) but mostly focused on slaughtering tons of enemies to earn gems to help you power up your character and hoping for some rare loot drops and component drops to help you purchase (although it's a light forging system) better equipment. I respect those who wanted to master this system as it does have some depth to it, but for me it was missing some QOL (like ability to zoom out of the skill tree and see the different routes and abilities/skills you could learn) and was very repetitive in a button mashing way in game, with some instances that casting a spell was useful. It was not my cup of tea. 3/5.
Story: I only got through chapter 4 in terms of the story. You have a brief cut scene that sets that stage for our amnesiac and silent protagonist with the only thing he remembers and the talking crow, Karon, that accompanies him. There are a few side characters and temporary characters that accompany you on your quests, but I did not find them very well interesting in the 7 hours I played. Perhaps the story gets better from here, but there wasn't much drawing me in and I felt no connection to any of the characters and only mildly interested in Karon. 3/5.
Music: If you want some electric guitar (which is my jam) get ready for a lot of it. Very generic guitar wailing during your action scenes and slower music during the rest of the time all fairly forgettable. 2/5.
Graphics: You can tell from the trailer what you're getting, fairly cheap graphics but considering it was a small team putting this together you can't expect much. While not a graphic issue per se, I found the level layouts to be very bland, but they do differentiate each chapter with different areas although you'll be running back and forth within an area quite often. I didn't care for the aesthetic and especially didn't like how ridiculously huge your weapons were compared to the character's size, but to each their own. 2/5.
Fun-factor: From nearly the beginning this was a grind. I had to look up some guides to get started as the in-game instruction only gets you so far. one particularly grueling platforming section made me so frustrated until I finally found a walk through showing that you had to unlock a specific ability prior to progressing - something that the game doesn't indicate for you as it seems to tell you to explore your builds, but really you do need to obtain certain abilities in linear progression based fashion (double jump, invincible jump, etc). Stuff like this really soured my enjoyment of the game and made a lot of it more of a job to figure out exactly where you're meant to go next as I had assumed that I was at an impassable point and tried running through the levels multiple times to see if I had missed something. 2/5.
Overall: If this game looks like your jam, more power to you. If you're on the fence and think the overwhelming positive reviews are enough to sway you (like they did me) I'd just check out a few more walk through videos to see exactly what you're getting into before you get this. This one while a labor of love is rough in all aspects and I think there's better games out there. 2/5.

Pretty amazing side-scrolling RPG (especially considering small dev team) with reasonably complex combat and thoroughly complex plot. +Every item has detailed inventory art

+Re-spec nearly anywhere

144070272.review:
AstLibra Revision is pretty incredible. I came into this game knowing basically nothing, it was just this interesting-looking side scroller that was highly rated that I bought on sale. And here I am almost 70 hours later, absolutely blown away at the end of it all. So, let me shill this game and talk a little more about it.

Overall: 9/10
- This game is not perfect, and has its flaws, but I believe it is very worth giving a shot if you enjoy action games, JRPGs, metroidvanias, etc. There is even a demo to play to give it a shot, although the demo throws so much at you at once, I honestly think it's better to just jump straight into the game itself. There is a lot of information and systems to understand, and its definitely digestible in context of the game and story, but not so much all-at-once. Also this is my score on my feeling for the overall game, I'm not averaging my scores based on some individual sections.

Story: 9.5/10
I was shocked at the story of this game. I really did not see a lot of what happened over the course of the game coming. There are times that get a little uncomfortable because of over-done fanservice and some of the character writing, but overall it's insignificant compared to the twists and turns and genuinely interesting paths the story takes (I really would go more into it, but I don't want to spoil). Seeing the story through to the post-game end was very satisfying, and I would definitely recommend even to those who may be hesitant based on how the game looks or even if they did not enjoy the combat as much. 

Visuals: 7.5/10
AstLibra Revision is an odd-looking side scroller at first glance. The character models sort of float in front of the backgrounds as these very clear 2D images and the combat animations are also nothing to write home about. As you progress in the game as well you will notice that there are a significant amount of enemies with very horny designs as well, which also made me uncomfortable at times. Overall, however, the art design and direction for many of the bosses, weapons, armors, etc. impressed me and were very detailed. I think the visuals are the weakest part about this game, especially if you aren't into the fan service, but not a deal-breaker by any means.

Music & Sound: 8/10
There are genuinely some bangers in the ost 100%. However, songs will loop quite a bit in the sections of the game that they play in enough that you may get a little tired of them, so it's not perfect. Music most of the time was nice and added to the atmosphere to some story scenes significantly. Besides the music, most of the time you'll be hearing the combat sounds over everything else, and it can definitely get loud at times compared to the rest of the game. There are also quite a few re-used sound effects between bosses, magic, and many of the weapons sound the same as well. Can get a bit repetitive, but I still liked it even at the end of the game.

Combat: 9/10
I think this is the biggest love it or hate it part of the game. I think to enjoy the game overall, it's important to enjoy the combat as it is the biggest portion of it. Weird hitboxes on attacks and the absolute reliance on magic to help invulnerability yourself through some genuinely stupid attacks during fights are my only real complaints. The weight system is interesting because as you progress in the game, weapons get heavier and heavier, and you need to level agility to be able to move and wield them with any sufficiency at all. High-weight combat is worse than fat-rolling in souls-likes because you cant even swing your weapon, you're just locked into the animations as they slowly roll through. However, if you get your weight to 0 (which I HIGHLY recommend) you are machine-gunning attacks and building your magic gauge incredibly fast so you become a dps god and can focus more attention on the rest of the fight. Magic and abilities are also incredibly important, but many of these are earned through a progression grid or mastering weapons & equipment, so the game can feel a bit grindy sometimes. Combat itself is very simple, but there are several systems at play, so there is a satisfying amount of prep-work and builds you can put together for different fights. I had a ton of fun with the combat, and while it does take some getting used to, I think it would appeal to many action game fans.

Performance: 8/10
This game is not very intensive and usually runs pretty smooth, but there are times in combat that there is genuine game lag when there is a lot happening. The entire game just slows down briefly when it happens, but I never experienced any crashing or performance spikes on my computer. It's there and noticeable when it does happen, but it didn't really impact my experience with the game. There were also several times that enemies would fly halfway off the screen and drop chests that I couldn't grab because they ended up in the wall, which is kind of annoying. I think this is more a design decision than a bug however. I did not experience bugs that I can recall. Overall, I was satisfied with the games performance. 

With how much I enjoyed AstLibra Revision and for the amount of time I enjoyed it, I gladly would have paid full-price, even $80+ for this game. This game at $25 is still a steal, and it goes on sale quite a bit as well. Definitely check this gem of a game out.

So I'm almost on the fence for this one, sadly.

First off, the cons: controls, general jank/bugginess, writing, formulaic design.

The controls are pretty stiff and awkward and, weirdly far into the game, they suddenly introduce extra abilities which are activated in roundaboutly simple ways, such as "hold down in air", which will then start activating when you're trying to "hold down and attack" in air to do a down-slash and mess up your 30+ hours of muscle memory. At minimum these skills should be able to be *toggled* on or off as far as if they can activate or not. Holding down is also block, which you *can* do mid-air, so it becomes impossible to do so without also activating the other thing. Really, reaaaaaaalllyy clunky.

The enemy telegraphs, hit boxes, etc., are pretty rough. Enemies get stuck in walls, treasures fall where you can't reach them, screens don't move with you and you get stuck, lots of quirky engine stuff. None of it was game stopping, but several of them could be - and there's no autosave, so you could really get screwed by that. Several parts of the game are also needlessly obtuse - solution to X puzzle is right in front of you, you understand it, but you didn't talk to random NPC *three* times before attempting to solve it, so you can't solve it and are confused. Enemy attacks will clip through terrain - yours don't usually. Some abilities do more harm than good. Block and counter damage? Great, but then you get no iframes after the attack and are in the middle of the enemy that you just blocked the attack of and thus take damage, making it usually useless if not downright detrimental to use. Stuff like that. 

The writing is pretty stiff to say the least, it definitely exudes the translated vibe. A proper, localized pass with some better writing for the characters' voices and all would go so very far. The story is actually not too bad and has some interesting beats (though also some pretty cringe-y ones, especially those dealing with suggestive situations or female characters), but the writing pulls a good bit of the punch it could otherwise have.

Almost every single chapter starts to feel same-y - go in, story/fight to a midpoint, story/fight, boss, return. This doesn't feel too bad except that many of the materials you need to craft new gear, and obtain most your abilities, only comes from the *second* half of each chapter.. ergo the obvious way to play is to rush the first part and grind the second. It makes it feel a bit too rigid and predictable. Having actual enemy variety, discover-ability and such would go far.

All that said, it has a good bit going for it, the gameplay and combat are decent once you get a feel for it, and I liked all the unlockables based on gear and whatnot. Later in some of the enemies and areas get pretty cheap and thus can be a bit frustrating. The "XP" system is neat as far as having a huge pseudo-passive tree with interesting-ish unlockables strewn about (handful of abilities, special gear, etc.) The point-type system for setting abilities unlocked from gear is solid.

I can see the "diamond in the rough" that the game seems to be regarded most for but I'd almost say it's more of a *rough* diamond in the rough. The edges are fuzzy for sure - with polish I think it'd still be a little off feeling, with polish *and* better writing it could really knock it out of the park.

Ultimately, though, mostly positive, but much of the roughness shines through a bit too brightly to be ignored, especially with many of the other systems have their own roughness or shortcomings.

edit: I will say, as a tack-on thought, the post game is shockingly good - frankly it should've been rolled into the whole game. The board system and such adds a neat level of depth/variety for gear, whereas throughout the game proper otherwise you just unlock skills and then use the strongest, there's not much reason to choose or vary. Also the story doesn't feel "post-game-y" at all, they really should've just added it as a few extra chapters to expand the original parts! I'm also very relieved it's not just a standard "new game+ do it again for some reason with nothing new", so really great job there.

edit edit: Sadly the last boss of the most game is really awful. WAY too much garbage on screen, your summons cover up projectiles, attacks are random and not patterned in a way that you can learn/improve, and every hit does way more damage than any other boss/enemy leading up to it, dead in 2-hits at most with three spews of projectiles covering the screen at most points.. It's weird because most bosses up to this point were similarly badly telegraphed and all but the damage was low enough that you could work through it. So I just finished spending 57 hours being completely absorbed and compelled by a game of which I had understandably low expectations. And man was I blown away. I do not usually review games - I just play them and move on - but man this is different. 

The screenshots, previews, and the demo that comes with the game understandably temper your expectations. The backgrounds and environments are off-putting the first time you see them. And the combat feels stiff. And the story line in the opening few chapters feels a bit aimless and stock-standard (you have amnesia and are trying to find your hometown - this feels like it has been done quite a few times). 

But the strength of this game is that it grows on you and continually develops. The action gets more and more fast paced and satisfying. I can't emphasize enough how good the combat gets and feels. I had more fun with the combat in this game than other Action RPGs like Nier Automata. With a lot of those games, you just mash the dodge button over and over again. With Astlibra, you charge into the fray of battle, execute combos, and devastate your opponents with combos and magic. It's all so satisfying. 

And the graphics grow on you. They mesh perfectly with the combat and magic graphics. Some of the animations for the gods and mechs look surreal. 

The design Keizo implemented into the game encourages grinding and fighting. He wants you to battle and enjoy yourself. And you are rewarded for it!  You get crafting items, and a multitude of other types of experience to grow and power up your character - and it all feels so intuitive.  Nothing is hidden, and you always feel rewarded for your time commitment. 

The storyline is probably the most unique narrative I have come across in a long time. it starts our so simple, so that you (the player) are not expecting much. But layers and layers keep getting added on, and when they all come  together, you are taken aback - you simply are not expecting the plot twists. And the ending ties up all the loose ends perfectly. Others have mentioned that you can't go into the storyline much without giving too much away, and i agree. You should experience it for yourself. I will say this, though, that crow is my ultimate bro. 

If you are a fan of action RPGs, or RPGs in general, or if you grew up during the 90s and 2000s with RPGs like Chrono Trigger, Xenogears, or maybe even Ragnarok Online, play this game. You will have a blast.

143056004.review:
ASTLIBRA is an absolute gem of a game. Its an action JRPG/platformer with all of its standard fare, but with the added bonus of everything being really well done, having good gameplay mechanics, an amazing soundtrack, and a fantastic story to keep you immersed in the game.

The game is an action JRPG, so nothing turn-based about the gameplay. The action is smooth and really fine-tuned, at least in my opinion, and that becomes especially apparent as you grind and raise your stats. One part of the game has some elements in it that are added to the existing game later on and it opens up the possibilities for all manner of grinding and stat min-maxing. The weapons handle different and weight will determine how fast or slow you go with a weapon based on what type of weapon it is (some weapons are slower than others, and some are really fast). Weapon range and handling also play a factor in how well a fight goes. On top of this, there is a growth tree that can up you stats and give you summoning skills that are really helpful through out the game (and some are so helpful that they are on par with the most powerful summons you can obtain). On top of all of that, there is the Libra system where you can put items on a scale that gives you even more stats or resistances and even allow for more money/force (used in the growth tree)/experience gain. Balancing it perfectly allows you to get the stat boosts and such from both sides of the scale without them being diminished on one side versus the other. 

The weapons, armors, and shields are all items that you can play with and level which will net you either some new abilities that you can select later or magic crystals that will allow you to equip said abilities if you are not using the item in question. If you equip the item with an ability, you can choose to equip that ability with no extra cost to your magic crystal pool, which is a great way to maximize your usage of abilities to their fullest. Accessories do not come with any leveling mechanic so they are static (at least until the latter half of the game). There is also a new customization mechanic later in the game that will enhance weapons, armors, shields, and accessories that can not only up the stats of everything, but allow for changes to abilities or adding new stats, which was a interesting answer to the usual "I've grinded all the stuff, now what?" question and even attachments that can be added to them (although most of it comes with RNG, so there is a reason to continue grinding to get the best stuff). 

The story itself is absolutely wonderful, well written, and executed so well done that it ties up all manner of loop-holes very well, including ones that you didn't even know it had (or forgot about which is a phenomenal surprise when you realize some things later on or remember certain characters). It has its tense moments, which are assisted by the gameplay obviously, its funny moments, its sad moments, and some of the twists you don't completely see coming either. It does well in foreshadowing some events and even some inconsequential story pieces end up showing up when you least expect it, There are some things that are predictable and, again, this is a JRPG so it has many of the staples embedded in the story, but it works in its favor rather than to its determent, or at least I think so. 

Its been a while since I've played another game as enjoyable as this one. I absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking for a good JRPG to enjoy your time with that has the right amount of gameplay mechanics, story, and overall enjoyment that can be found in ASTLIBRA. I hope to see more games from this developer that are as fun and enjoyable as this game was.

I haven't quite played a game like this since "Death's Gambit" (now "Death's Gambit: Afterlife"), ENDER LILIES, or NieR/NieR:Automata. It seems that the "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews and the absurdly high number (~33%) of all players that got the "True Ending" are for a reason, after all.

When I first saw the game, I thought it looked ugly and that the gameplay looked boring. I could not be happier to have been wrong, as it ended up being a fantastic game. The story was great - full of twists and turns, insanely increasing stakes and comedic relief. The gameplay was surprisingly fun - fluid and responsive with lots of different abilities to master and press. There is a giant skill grid called "Grow" in addition to a traditional leveling system and an armor/weapon/shield mastery system that also unlocks various skills ("KARON"). There is blocking, and i-frame dodging ("Backstep") and i-frame magic to avoid damage or even heal.

As it turns out, the reason for both the initial off-putting impression and it actually being really good is that it was made by a single developer over the course of 15 years; a mixture of extremely limited resources/budget and it apparently being something he really wanted to make; something he himself wanted to play -- a rarity in a world where games are made by a boardroom decreeing they want yet another seven Assassin's Creed games being made simultaneously.

I would not really advise playing on the highest difficulty as all it really does is extend grinding periods, but you can freely change it for the duration of the first chapter so you can easily see for yourself. Hard difficulty is probably the best balance between grinding and being a completionist.

An amazing one-man accomplishment, for sure.

A grandes rasgos, es un Action RPG de scroll lateral con un desarrollo bastante lineal. La trama se divide en capítulos (es un puntazo que cuando empiezas un nuevo capítulo se muestra el opening del juego, como si estuvieramos viendo un anime) y son bastante directos (sin misiones secundarias de comprar ajos tan de moda en los Triple A ni historias. Si llevas un arma de dos manos, pues te la paras con el pecho) y un dash para esquivar con un pequeño cooldown. Conforme vas jugando, vas aprendiendo más técnicas.

Y ahora es cuando llega la madre del cordero, la cerecita en lo alto del pastel, la punta del iceberg, la... personalización del personaje. Amazing RPG platformer that I can't recommend enough. It's a sidescrolling 2D RPG (Think Metroidvania with less focus on exploration) with a very cool skill and combat system. Using your partner to use "possession skills" you can summon or transform into various spirits of different elements using a very intuitive casting system (almost like fighting game inputs rather than menu navigation), in addition to your weapons, armors, and shields teaching you passive skills (similar to Final Fantasy IX) and a MASSIVE skill tree to increase your stats and learn new spells. 

It's also quite long, often with a "just when you think you're done, there's a new arc of the story" factor that feels great. Playing on Hard is a good balance of difficulty, and it's not particularly grindy. With optional bosses, lots of completionist achievements, and postgame methods of improving your character and gear, you'll be fully occupied all the way to the end.

The story is actually pretty good too. A lot of twists, turns, drama, and comic relief, none of which overstays its welcome. There is some time travel in the plot so as you can expect things get pretty crazy, but it's never convoluted or hard to follow. 

The only cons I can really give are bugs so minor as to be negligible (a certain achievement not unlocking until a complete game restart for instance) some translational errors (to instead of too) and in my opinion some of the terrain construction looks a bit odd with how tiles match up. None of this is so obvious or egregious as to be distracting from the overall quality but I would be remiss in not mentioning it. 

Despite these cons, I can only recommend it. An absolutely masterful RPG and an independent one no less. Not perfect, but just about as close as you can get.

ASTLIBRA on the surface reminds me of a game I would've played in the early-mid 2000s with aesthetics that look like it would've been a polished remaster, but this works favorably and the game + its environments are GORGEOUS. It's nostalgic while at the same time not? Chapters 6-7 are probably my favorite. 
The story and characters are introduced in an episodic tone of sorts (the chapters) where between each chapter you're at a small hub world where you can revisit past areas. It works great, and the characters are nicely written. Note there was a second English translation that polished up the original which is what I played. I may try the original on a 2nd playthrough but I heard it was rough. Who knew stories about [spoiler]time/space travel[/spoiler] could still be handled well? A couple of weird moments in Chapter 4 & I personally wasn't as crazy about Chapter 8, but what comes after these chapters more than make up for it. 
The music reminds me of Ys/Falcom games with a mix of Anime OP stuff whiel also being varied. Basically, the music selection is outstanding and I learned late into the game a lot of it is royalty free. The sound design is also excellent, especially in gameplay.
Which brings me to my last point: the gameplay. Mechanically it starts off simple, but it gradually adds more mechanics, opportunities to boost your stats, unlocks to enhance your base moves, and rewards experimentation and grinding. Yes, there is grinding in this game but the sound design and all the goodies you get from beating up your enemies and maintaining a high combo give you so much dopamine and adrenaline that you WANT more of it, and working towards these unlocks and wondering what you will get next is so much fun and it never feels overwhelming to lean or too tedious and boring to work through. The difficulty is reasonably challenging. Some spots around midgame and later do make you work for learning the mechanics like using your shield, juggling items and spells, but they never got too frustrating. The sidequests and going out of your way to find extra rewards are actually worth the effort too. This game REWARDS you greatly instead of just giving you a piece of gear you may stop using shortly after. There is also one more aspect of gameplay I'd like to talk about, but I'm putting it in spoilers out of respect for those who want to find it out for themselves. 
Be warned.
[spoiler]
After you beat the game, you unlock a post-game/pseudo NG+ that takes all the growth you've done up to that point and cranks it up to 12. Every piece of gear you get can be enhanced with these "command boards" you find in loot and these can do anything from adding more stats to increasing the diminishing returns threshold on your level up point allocation to modifying your abilities and skills. Not only that, but you can enhance pretty much all of your gear infinitely(?) by using leftover materials you've found throughout your adventure. That's right. Pretty much every piece of gear becomes a potential option in gameplay. Oh but that's not all. Your growth tree extends massively. There's also a secret involving the scales, but I won't spoil that. This post-game stuff is, in my opinion, brilliant game design and takes the game from a 10 to an 11 for me. 
[/spoiler]

I'm really glad I came across this game when I did because it has become one of my favorite experiences of all time, and I have a lot of respect for the developer sticking with it and working on it for years. Very inspiring.

[h1]Castlevania & Chrono Trigger Had a Baby and its Name is ASTLIBRA Revision[/h1]
[b]Do you enjoy addicting combat? Compelling stories? Memorable characters? A KICKASS soundtrack that sticks with you even after you've stopped playing? This game has all of that, and so much more![/b] Look, when I first saw this game, I told myself, "damn, this looks a bit dated. I proceeded to try the free demo, went absolutely wild with all the fun equipment, magic, and tools you're given to play with, and got extremely interested in the brief bit of story that was teased. It was a little overwhelming at first due to how much stuff you're given to test out, but I bit the bullet, bought the game, and went on an emotional roller coaster that kept me invested every step of the way!

[b]Story (no spoilers):[/b] My god, where to begin? You're an orphan who got separated from your childhood friend, and you set out on a quest to find her. A simple enough premise, but add a talking crow, some magic scales that give you the ability to travel through space and time, and you've got yourself a recipe for a plot that will keep you guessing up to the very end! You'll meet so many wonderful, memorable characters that will win your heart and make you want to do everything in your power to help them, even if that means making some very difficult decisions. In the end, you'll grow to love your companions, especially your talking crow, and you'll come to appreciate how much you've accomplished together.

Time and fate are, of course, key themes of this story, and you'll leave every session thinking about how the story relates to your own life, and be inspired to take your precious time on this earth more seriously. I can not emphasize enough how much this story will stick with you as you slowly but surely make your way through every chapter.... it's a masterpiece.

[b]15 YEARS IN THE MAKING:[/b] Did I mention that a single dude poured his heart and soul into this game? Every played Stardew Valley? That game had a similar development cycle, and it was friggen AMAZING - same holds true here - Keizo has truly perfected his vision for the experience he wants players to feel as they progress through this game, and I can 100% attest to that. I'm not ashamed to admit I wanted to cry a few times through the story.

[b]ADDICTING COMBAT:[/b] Ok, let's say you don't care much for story - that's ok, you're gonna love this game's combat. Swords, hammers, maces, axes, magic staves/wands, bows, crossbows, guns, and much, much more are available for you to use and abuse on your enemies. You've got an extremely rewarded leveling system that makes you really feel like you're growing in strength from your battles, and it's extremely fun being able to harvest materials and craft new equipment for yourself as you progress through the map.

[b]EXTREMELY CATCHY/MEMORABLE SOUNDTRACK:[/b] Friends, when you boot up that demo and start fighting a few demons, the very first song you hear is going to give your ears an orgasm. I kid you not, the official game has the most BADASS music to go along with you fighting beginner enemies! Keizo didn't need to go that hard, but that's just an appetizer for what you're going to be enjoying as you play. The music, like the story and combat, gets better, and better, AND BETTER, AND BETTER. Every single stage of this game kept blowing me away with how great the soundtrack is!

I'm a guy who likes to exercise to kickass tunes, and I can tell you now, Astlibra Revision's soundtrack has been added to my lifting and cardio playlists. Simply put: this is the greatest JRPG music I've heard in a LONG while, and I've played a lot of fantastic JRPGs with banger soundtracks... this is in a league of its own... similar yet arguably better than the music you'd hear in the YS series.

[b]TL;DR[/b] Look, I don't write reviews often. See that giant wall of text up there? It means: THIS GAME IS AMAZING! BUY IT RIGHT NOW! You could wait for a sale if you like, but I guarantee that this is one of those rare gems that's worth every single penny. You're going to remember this game for the rest of your life.

Thank you, Keizo, for sharing your passion and vision with the world. Your game has truly touched my heart and I've a greater appreciation for life and the journey I've taken to reach this point. We can't go back in time IRL, but you've taught me that we can always fight for a better future. Truly, this game is a masterpiece in every sense of the word...

#1 Recommendation, start on Difficult/Hard to get the best experience out of the mechanics and to not just stomp through everything. The mechanics are what make this game fun.


After playing 101 hours and getting all the achievements here is my full review of this game:


STORY: (6/10)
The first thing I want to address is the story. In some parts it feels like a well done fanfic rather than a professionally edited story. There are some plot holes; there are some plot lines stolen from other things and poorly integrated into the game (Chapter 4 is the worst for this); there are parts that are super cheesy; there are parts where you are going to roll your eyes and facepalm; BUT, I feel like the story as a whole was engaging enough to be enjoyable. It goes in some pretty interesting directions and there are a few pleasant surprises. If it really bothers you though every part of the story can be skipped. For the most part, the chapters flow well and the climaxes usually feel satisfying. Basically what I'm getting at is that it is good enough.  


MECHANICS: (9/10)
This is where this game shines. There are several different progression systems in the game that interweave and support each other flawlessly without becoming over-complex. It is a rather addicting progression cycle. There are a lot of ways to play into the mechanics and quite a few different play styles work well within the limits of the system, so you can customize combat to your preferences. The hit boxes are well done, and the fighting is fairly intuitive. The bosses are surprisingly well done, and I found very few disappointing duds on my playthough. The one issue that I found with combat is that between the bosses flashy moves, and your flashy moves, sometimes the screen can get a little cluttered and it can become difficult to see where you need to dodge.


ART: (6/10)
The art is stylized. I think that the aesthetic fits well with the story and it gives you the feeling that you are reading a generic manga off a pirate website. Overall the art is decent for an indie game and I kind of like it 


MUSIC: (5/10)
The music is not the best. I think it is clips of royalty free music looped. It didn't hinder my experience too much, but it is probably the part of the game that could use the most improvement. The other sound effects were decent though. 


Well, I've basically said what I wanted to say. It was a good game and I feel like I got my money's worth out of it. Just to reiterate, starting at a higher difficulty is recommended. I started at the normal difficulty and found that, after a small amount of grinding, I was slaughtering everything with little resistance and it was not that exciting. Also, after the early game is over you can't make the difficulty higher, only lower. So I ended up losing a few hours of game time when I restarted to change to Difficult/ Hard mode because I wasn't having fun on normal. After making the switch the game felt much better and I enjoyed it to the end. Lastly, do yourself a favor and don't spoil the story by looking at the achievements until after you are finished with the post game. None of the achievements are miss-able (except completing the game in hard mode), and even after the game is over you can go back and complete them. The story is already shaky enough without spoilers lol.

141649240.review:
Do not be fooled by people saying this game is a generic jrpg.  The game definitely starts with some common jrpg elements such as a childhood friend, amnesia, and an animal mascot guide.  However, at the very beginning, I have never seen a jrpg story hook that starts with "and then the main character and his animal companion wanders through a seemingly endless forest for eight years."

I mostly watched my girlfriend play this game since she really wanted to play it after I beat the first boss of the game, but there were a lot of elements of this game I could appreciate even just watching.  The storyline has a lot of subtle references and foreshadowing that don't seem significant, and then later it blows you away by showcasing them as central focal points of the story.  Much like Dark Souls, even small tidbits of lore you find in pages on the ground such as gods, otherworldly beings, and concepts about the world become relevent to the story.  You read about a god of war?  You actually encounter said god in the story.

The way they present dialogue is also quite good and shows a particular attention to detail.  The dialogue has natural slowdowns and pauses as if the characters are actually talking, and it feels incredibly natural to read.  This takes a lot of time to attention to detail to perform itself considering how much dialogue is in the story.

It's sad to say, but it has been a long time since I've seen a story with main characters who genuinely try their best.   I didn't see too much woe is me type of characterization while watching this game all the way past post game.  The attitude of everyone is generally hopeful while still having moments of heart breaking despair throughout the storyline.  There isn't any character in this story I was actively annoyed with, which is a feat because I typically find animal mascot companion characters extremely annoying (looking at you Paimon), but Karon ended up being one of the most endearing characters I genuinely cared about.

The gameplay is simple and easy to get into.  There are many ways to optimize your character and instill growth from leveling up, the grow tree, balancing libra scales, equipment, mastery of equipment, customizing Karon skills, enhancing scale pans, enhancing equipment, setting scale boards, mastering/using different possession skills, and gaining new techniques.  The game encourages you to use and collect every piece of equipment (except accessories) since mastering equipment grants you magic crystals to use more Karon skills or gives you a new Karon skill entirely.  You can distribute your level up stats however you want and redistribute them however you wish very easily.  Techniques you don't want to accidentally use can even be sealed temporarily.

I watched this game being played on Hell difficulty, and the beginning of the game is quite difficult but becomes more manageable as you continue playing.  Enemies are not to be taken lightly on the hardest difficulty you can play when you start up the game, you can die typically within a few hits.  However, there are a lot of systems in place to mitigate damage, but none of them are able to be used infinitely.  The backdash has a cooldown, guard has a guard gauge you have to watch, some attacks can't be guarded, and possession skills have i-frames but aren't immune to status effects (unless you equip a very expensive Karon skill) and use ST.  This game is not impossible on the hardest difficulties, but it is not easy.  Only after gaining access to specific Karon skills that boost magic power was the game starting to reach the godlike game breaking power I'm used to from most jrpgs.

In the past, the game supposedly had a poor translation, however I only esperienced the game post translation edit patch.  I must say, whatever bad translation was part of the game doesn't seem to be present.  Occasionally I'll see the random grammatical error, but nothing that breaks the immersion of the game.  If you are worried about this, don't be.

Atlibra Revision is an epic adventure game about a hero's journey with many twists and turns, as well as endearing characters.  The gameplay is entertaining and easy to get into with many aspects of grinding to improve your power level.  The grind is more of an equipment and item grind like Monster Hunter, the best kind of grinding.  After fifty hours of gameplay, the game still isn't done yet.  Recommended unless you don't like anime for some reason.

Did not expect to have as much CRAZY FUN as I had. I'm not usually a fan of this genre (odin sphere, castlevania, metroidvania), but the combat in Astlibra just feels ridiculously fun, thanks to its' hitstop implementation. Really well done to the DEV KEIZO.

Combat starts out simple, but the arsenal quickly builds up. Unlike castlevania games where you can only equip a few special abilities and you pretty much just use whatever is strongest, Astlibra allows for over 10 sword techniques concurrently, while still giving you access to 6 different spells at any time. The gameplay is fluid, feels amazing to hit, and gives much flexibility to encounter each boss your way. 

Astlibra also doesn't contain much of the annoying fluff in metroidvania, where you need to unlock new abilities and go back to old areas to get unlocks. Every chest/unlocks can be gotten in their own specific chapter, without the need for much backtracking.

The story starts off interesting enough, with enough intrigue to make you want to find out more. The main cast is likeable, believable and well developed with individual backstories and connections. After they throw a few plot twists to you, the story keeps climbing upwards in the best way possible. You may need to follow a guide though, as there are quite a few false happy endings. There is a japanese guide wikia, which you can use google translate for.

The story is easily the second best highlight of the game for me, it's not a cliche generic plotline. I will remember the storyline for a long long time to come. The pacing is well done and I was surprised a few times throughout, with my story guesses turning out to be wrong in a good way. The soundtrack contains over 140 tracks and I'll look for certain tracks even after I have finished the game.

This game, together with Demons Roots and The Last Sovereign, renewed my enjoyment and love for video games in the 2020s era. In fact, Astlibra might possibly be my GOTY for 2023, as I cannot remember the last time I had so much enjoyment out of a game in recent years. 

I eagerly await the upcoming side story content by KEIZO regarding the baker's daughter revision, as well as future games by KEIZO.

A bit of downside is that given its a JRPG, there's a lot of irrelevant fanservice that does not service the story but it is what it is. The story could be a bit overarching sometimes specially at the late game to postscript, but the whole experience of picking up clues, piecing up events, and overall the whole story ride is rewarding to say the least.

The Postscript does not just give you lazy content and actually has plot in it. They also introduce 2 more systems that COMPLETELY CHANGES THE GAMEPLAY for post script and I somehow wish that they have integrated it right from the start, but I can see why they don't since it will be hard to balance the game throughout the main story. Achievements are super easy to accomplish to the point that the only thing I need to grind for an achievement is the walking 50,000 steps one since I need 5,000 more after I finished all the game has to offer. it took me 55 Hours in-game time to be exact. All in all, The devs really wanted you to have fun at this game. Gameplay has been carefully balanced and thought out; Story has an incredible introduction that made it rough on its edges when concluding it, but It tried its best to tie it up at the end; Soundtracks a banger; Postscript is entertaining as hell; and you can see the thought that is given for this game to be this good.

I will tune in to the next KEIZO game for sure. Maybe about the Baker's Daughter?  O_O

Near the end of the game, in one of the final save rooms, the song that plays is a slowed down version of the town music you've heard throughout the game. Its the game saying its almost done, and while you wish the ride would continue, the journey was already very long, and its time to say goodbye. Very few games make give this fulfilling experience of a complete ride, and this game hits way above its weight.

Like others mention, this isn't so much a throwback game as it is a game made with passion from a gaming era where games were not designed to be movie experiences, but to be games. The combat is solid and delivers in truckloads, the boss fights (that throw less than 4 characters at you at the same time) are a blast, room layout is thoughtful, enemy design is like the best stuff 2d games used to throw at players before 2010. Players are free to change their stat point allocation at shop locations, and there's a lot of weapons and accessories to mess around with to resolve hard fights. Music goes hard, why the ost isn't on sale is beyond explanation, along with an artbook that would help flesh out the rest of the world.

The game's progression is the secret sauce to the whole experience. There's the story that, after the dialogue heavy intro, continues at a much faster pace. Then there's leveling up, which happens at an acceptable rate. Each weapon/armor/shield has a mastery that never takes too long and usually grants a permanent ability to be slotted, and to get new gear you have to forge them through monster drops, that come in just fast enough that once some of your gear is mastered, you've got enough loot to make new gear that has other abilities you want to know. On top of that, there's a growth system kind of like a simplified version of FFX sphere grid, so the player is intermittently leveling something up on their own. All these progression systems are running simultaneously, so the player always feels like they're two steps away from another milestone, and this is all on top of a solid 2d action game.

The game isn't flawless, as some puzzles make really no sense, like going through invisible walls that are actually corridors of invisible walls, or doors that are placed just above your ankles yet you can unlock them and walk through them like the ceiling doesn't exist. Bosses 3+ enemies attacking you can get nigh-impossible with no enemy giving you breathing room to reactively block, so the solution is just out-dps the situation. Playing the game on impossible difficulty to the very end, there are fights late game that feel more luck based than skill based.

The greatest criticism for the game is the demo: the combat section gives you a bunch of high level gear so the actual nuance and difficulty of the real game is not felt, and the text-heavy intro presents the game like its a by-the-books jrpg story when it really starts pulling the rug and the whole house midway through the game. Really wish they just let the player play the entirety of chapter 1 as that it ends with the narrative hook the game hangs on.

For those still reading this, the recent translation patch is solid. Maybe a weird word placement once or twice, but its nitpicking. The translation feels faithful. Also, max difficulty is doable but you will get cheap shotted a lot - the game lets you adjust difficulty until end of chapter 2 so best to play with that setting until the game hard stops you from raising it. Its a great game, a great experience, and hope for the best for any future projects the indie developers delve into. If they're reading this, thank you, and please release the ost and/or an artbook in the meantime.

Personally I don't think this game is like Castlevania SotN or Bloodstained, more of a linear RPG with similar combat. 


[b]PROs[/b]
====
Amazingly beautiful character and sprite artwork (REALLY really nice)

Tons of content and optional bosses that can be tricky to beat

Karon and Gau have amusing personalities

Incredibly wide weapon, armor, and accessory options that all look fantastic

Lots of ability to modify your character build and min/max 

Earning special attributes from the weapons is a fantastic idea and was well implemented

Spectacular looking and very useful spells that are easy to use on the fly

The story premise is interesting and more introspective than most

You can easily dodge the enemies if you don't feel like fighting them

[spoiler] The little floating house shop is a fun addition [/spoiler]

Save points are well spaced and restore life

Different difficulty options make the game accessible to all skill levels

Finding the hidden targets and arrows is entertaining

Controller support is excellent

Fun achievements to unlock in Steam



[b]CONs[/b]
====
The largest issue by far is that It can be very difficult to know what is foreground and background. This complicates progression as it can be difficult to know what to do next... platform assets are not obvious, hidden entrances can only be found by throwing yourself at walls, it would be nice if the background was blurred, had less contrast, was darker, etc.  

Music during fighting is frenetic rapid tempo electronica or synth rap that is irritating. This is my second least favorite part of the game. More approachable music would have been preferable. 

Tons of travelling back and forth solely for the sake of increasing game time

Cut scenes with the dialog feel long because of the constant ellipsis and pauses. 

While I normally love puzzles, many in this game seem obtuse and will require you to consult the web. 

Dialog has tropey anime stuff baked in [spoiler] (e.g. an overly prude/shy male female relationship, the tsundere, weird foot stuff, the feminine looking male who has to cross-dress to trick someone, women throwing themselves at the main char, the alcohol lush, the hot spring peeping scene, etc.) [/spoiler] 

I personally don't like the silent protagonist, but I realize it's an artistic choice. 

The decision to replay the intro after every chapter is strange, but at least can be skipped

Some artwork is taken from photos and is sometimes a 3D view which clashes with the 2D sprites, and the bridges that are a black silhouette are odd. 

[spoiler] A char dies and unless you have a recent save to fix your decision you just have to deal with it. [/spoiler]

Getting the ingredients you need for crafting can require plenty of mindless grinding until end game when your luck is much higher.



Ultimately at the end of the day I feel like the amount of content and effort easily justify the price, I find myself getting a little bored with the slow pacing, running back and forth over the same areas, grinding for drops, not being able to figure out what to do next, and rapid pressing the button to get through slow dialog scenes. I wasn't sure if I would finish the game but it gets better after Chapter 5 and is more enjoyable. 

My ideal version of this game would make the platforming surfaces more contrasting and obvious and make the background look like the background, add a couple more clues on what the character needs to do next, eliminate the fetch quests back and forth, allow the user to skip the dialog bubbles and pauses with a button press, and include some music that's not high tempo. 

If you have the patience to deal with the issues listed above, there is much fun and tons of content to be had.
