139793410.review:
Very good. Played on normal and wasn't too hard though starting from normal you could always turn the difficultly to easy. Total game time to complete is 30ish hrs(from what a dev had said), but I've grinded for nearly every possible item to acquire and master. Try out the demo first I implore you as it gives a rough grasp on the combat.

  The story is based around the Libra scales of time and fate which are the manifestation of the Goddess Astraea's powers. It's interesting, thought invoking, and largely linear [spoiler]with a few player decisions that are inconsequential in the grand scheme of the story here and there that make you feel guilt and remorse that maybe you made a wrong decision and could've maybe changed what happened if you rolled back a save. But don't feel too bummed out, as the bad things are intended to happen and fate can be changed. After the "Happy Ending?" game ending it lets you make a save and should you feel like you want more and load it you're put into the postscript which is essentially a new game plus, BUT where you can progress by enhancing the current gear you have and the story is that you're now starting over the story from the very beginning going through the same areas now with stronger enemies and twists to how the story played out before trying to get the ideal ending to the game[/spoiler].

  Only gripes with the story are that in two chapters there was an annoying amount of abrupt "oh you thought" moments where you think the chapter is over and you're leaving the zone only to be halted and told to go back up to three times before the chapter decides it's over. In the other chapter you think you're going to catch up to your friend as he's always just out of eyesight before you suddenly and coincidentally start having abrupt visions repeatedly as you chase throughout the zone like the developer is having fun teasing you with "but wait, there's more!" The last gripe is that after conclusion of every chapter you'll be re-watching the same cutscene over and over same as when you have to watch the Libra sending you back in time. These cutscenes are skippable, but I watch them the first 5-6 times as a brief intermission just to appreciate the journey so far and to collect your thoughts about whats happening in the story.  

  The gameplay is fantastical with combat based around techniques(combos), utilizing shields to bash(group them up for aoe) or parrying, dodges, magic skills, making use of I-frames, using weapons your enemy is weak against, putting items on the Libra scale and balancing them to gain their effects, making use of two-handers for their range advantage and bigger hitboxes if you can keep your agility high enough. A gross weight of 80 or higher is a no no akin to the dark souls "fat roll", so to avoid this either choose a lighter weapon/shield or give yourself higher agility to wield it effectively. Fire is weak against water, Earth is weak against Wind, Darkness(lightning) is weak against Holy and vice versa for a total of 6 elements, you can also see this by how the game has the magic skills ordered in the skill menu.

  Progression in this game is looking for treasure chests that contain very useful items. gathering materials and monster drops that're unique to each monster in a zone and purchasing every weapon, armor, shield, and accessories in the store then mastering them to either get a magic crystal or a Karon skill(passives). As well as gathering "force" from defeated enemies in order to spend in the Grow menu to grow your attributes, obtain weapons unobtainable elsewhere, and new magic skills. I highly recommend you master the tree branch at least by chapter 3 as it gives a Karon skill that improves the rate at which you master weapons. An example of how powerful your character could get by the end of the game is that your agility is high enough to have a gross weight of zero, having the "full burst" Karon skill that consumes your full ST bar to increase the power of your next magic skill in proportion to the amount consumed(there's two other variants of this skill) then casting the magic skill that increases your movement and swing speed. You'll be swinging so fast that the swing animation has to cancel itself for the next swing which is funny to look at and amazing to hear how fast you're landing hits on an enemy melting through them.

  I've haven't played anything quite like this before excluding the samey side-scroller rouge-likes that pad the game time by having you die a lot and starting over from the beginning. Definitively worth a play.

139790603.review:
What a game. In short, I don't think I've had this much pure FUN with a game in ages. 

To be a bit more verbose:

Astlibra presents as a love letter to a lot of games; the first impression gives that old Ys 3 feeling. Then it shows its love for Chrono Trigger. There are a lot of references buried in the game from Castlevania to Dragon Quest XI. The story takes some interesting turns until it goes entirely off the rails in the best way and stays there.

But the real heart of the game is its gameplay. Astlibra can be challenging at times but gives you so many tools to overcome anything it throws at you. If you like unlocking new stuff, this is the game for you. It never stops throwing new mechanics at you all the way until near the end of the post-game (that's a whole other post but suffice it to say there's lots to do). There are dozens of weapons, armors, shields and trinkets to unlock. There's crafting. Every single thing is worth digging into. Got a new weapon? Try it! It might not be your favorite but all the weapons feel good and fun to use. And mastering that weapon might grant you something useful!

The game is just a huge gift to gamers. It respects your time, plays with your expectations and never stops trying to wow you. 

It's an absolute juggernaut of a game and I cannot recommend it more. It may be my own personal GOTY of 2023.

I was pleasantly surprised when I played this game. It perfectly fulfilled my expectations for a game of this genre after playing "13 Sentinels: Aegis Rim." The story is just as captivating as other JRPG+sci-fi+cute girl games like "Nier" and "13 Sentinels."

While these types of games may not be extremely popular worldwide, I personally really enjoy them. However, I have to point out one thing. The script relies heavily on character illustrations. Many times, the reason I kept playing this game was that my wives (referring to the characters) are incredibly beautiful. I would be devastated if they died. If it were a man or an ugly woman who died, I wouldn't bother risking my life to save them. Consequently, the plot wouldn't progress either. As for the protagonist, his only motivation might be to save himself and the world.

Later in the text, it's mentioned that the gods specifically designed these scripts to train the male protagonist and challenge the rules established by the Creator. However, these scripts also seem too coincidental. It's stated that the male protagonist is the only one to reach the end among tens of thousands of parallel worlds. It's also said that the Divine Balance is actually a device to restart the entire floating island, not just time and space travel. Furthermore, it's mentioned that time and space travel did occur, and the gods bore the consequences. It's also said that the gods have abandoned humanity but want to train them to fulfill their purpose. Honestly, as I progressed, I found the setting of the script somewhat confusing. These settings are actually inconsistent. If the Divine Balance isn't a time and space travel device but just a repeated restart, then there's no need for the goddess to pay the price. The true time traveler is the artificial intelligence Anubis, who can send consciousness back in time. But that has nothing to do with the gods.

Overall, I feel that the author intentionally tried to make the script more logical and scientifically convincing, but it ended up creating some contradictions.

139572555.review:
A while back, I was fed up and tired of some of the more negative aspects of Astlibra, so I wrote a negative review for it and uninstalled it. But after a week or so, I realized I couldn't stop thinking about the game. So I gave it another shot... and I'm glad I did. I've changed my mind. This is a great game. But the game still isn't perfect, and I want to go over it's flaws first.

The game is less of an action-RPG and more JRPG-action. That isn't an inherently bad thing if you like JRPGs, but for me, I've found as I've gotten older I have less patience for these types of games. However, if you hate JRPGs to the core, I think you can stop reading here; you won't like this game. There is an action element to this game, certainly, and being better at action games will give you an advantage, but as compared to skill, your stats are much more of a deciding factor.

Speaking of stats, be prepared to grind. But not in the way you may think. There are a ton of things to collect in this game, but what I want to talk about is equipment. Armor, weapons, and shields all can be mastered by killing enough enemies with them equipped, which grants a permanent bonus or skill unlock; even when you don't have the weapon equipped. The thing is, you have to kill so many enemies that there's no way to progress through the game and master weapons naturally; you have to grind enemies over and over again if you want to master everything. Which believe me; you do. The bonuses are too good to pass up and mastering equipment is a big part of this game; that's just how it is.

There's also a lot of backtracking. Go A, then B, back to A, then B so you can go to C, then back to B so you can go back to A... etc. It isn't horrible, but I almost rolled my eyes a few times when story events unfolded in such a way that I had to go back to ABC AGAIN.

The grinding and backtracking gets in the way of progressing the story, which is cheesy and somewhat predictable... but at the same time, it's charming, and while there are a lot of things you'll see coming a mile away, there are also a few twists you'll never see coming. One of the best elements of the story is the characters, in my opinion. At the end of the game I realized that I was very fond of many of the... "main-side" characters in this game. Many of them had an external struggle or a personal weakness to overcome; a few had neither, some had both. When everything finished, it left me with an immensely satisfied feeling.

The game's story drastically improves when the "main game" ends and something called the "post-script" begins. Even though it's called the "post-script", many of the most important events in the game take place and some things that didn't make sense before start to add up. There's even new mechanics added. The post script is about 1/3 of the actual game, I'd say. With more interesting mechanics added(on top of the ones that were already interesting), less grinding and less backtracking, it's easily the strongest part of the game. I hope i'm not giving off the impression that you have to get through 2/3 of the game to get to the "good part", because everything before the post script is still worth playing on it's own, but I do wish the first part of the game played more like the second part. There is still some potential grinding in the postscript if you want to unlock everything though, especially if you had the misfortune to not find certain optional items that you could only find before the postscript... in which case, buckle up, because those items are an extremely rare drop.

A couple of other negatives I need to bring up; firstly, there's some odd progression issues in the story, as well as in equipment. You can acquire legendary swords early on that don't even remotely compare to normal equipment you'll find later, and your character will accomplish such unbelievable things that some of the conflicts later in the story seem silly after reflection. Secondly, this game has a few bugs. Reading a book for the very first time doesn't allow you to scroll down to read more text, and there's also a bug with a hidden ability that tells you how many unopened chests are still on-screen; if there are 4 of them you've found and 0 you haven't found, it will tell you 44. Nothing is game-breaking and I've never had the game crash once over 60+ hours so this is just a minor nitpick.

From here on out I only have praises to sing. The game's combat system is excellent, it's so good that even someone like me, who normally doesn't like hack-n-slash games, loves it. I don't have anything more to say, it's that good.

There's plenty of ways to make your character stronger. You can level up, which gives you crystals to allocate to stats. You can also acquire "force" by defeating enemies, which you can allocate to a growth tree to increase your stats that way. Furthermore, you can place items, which weigh different amounts, on a set of scales to get different kinds of bonuses; which vary by the item. The catch is that obviously, the scales need to be balanced. All this, PLUS all the mountains of equipment in the game, which can be upgraded and customized in the postscript. I wouldn't go as far as to say there's "builds" in this game but I'm willing to bet everybody's endgame character looks at least a little different from eachother's. 

There's plenty of hidden secrets to find by being attentive to your surroundings. They can be a big help, they're not just cosmetic or very small upgrades, so it pays to pay attention to your surroundings. Furthermore, while they aren't usually in plain sight, they're also not hidden in the kind of old-school, cryptic "how was I supposed to know that" way; if you search for long enough, you should be able to find pretty much everything on your own. Additionally, there's an optional area you can visit to complete challenges to earn even more upgrades.

The music is fantastic. I believe most if not all of it is free useage/open source, but it all sounds great and fits what the mood should be. I believe a good soundtrack is one of the most important parts of a game, and this passes with flying colors.

The art style is... interesting. I wouldn't say it's amazing, nor would I say it's bad, but I'm not sure I've seen anything that looks quite like this game, and it's grown on me to the point that I'd say I like it.

When it's all said and done, I think that this is a special game. Certainly it isn't perfect, but I doubt I'll ever forget it. If you're still on the fence, try the demo.

The combat feels mindless and grindy. The scale mechanic is the only somewhat interesting part of the gameplay; I obviously haven't explored it fully but from what I've read it doesn't appear to be an insanely must-play!!! level groundbreaking mechanic that changes the entire game.

139451972.review:
WIP review. I'll be updating this at some point. For now this is sort of a first impressions from someone whose only in chapter 3.

Yet again ANOTHER steam indie hit with overwhelmingly positive ratings that is at best mid, and at worst, quite bad. There's genuine merit to a lot of the base systems in the game. Weapons needing to be mastered so that you learn skills, exploring yielding skill points/new skills. The Libra scale system where you try to balance the "karmic" weights of two objects in order to buff yourself. The somewhat clunky but still neat Growth system where you use element drops you pick up from all the enemies to give yourself gradual buffs and eventually unlock new magic etc in a grid/node based system. The level up system is also based off getting "crystals" after each level up and choosing which stats to invest them into. VERY similar to that Dust: Elysian Tail game.  There's apparently even more system mechanics than just those. These are probably the strongest part of the game and all do a good job of supporting the main grinding loop.

Unfortunately, the actual gameplay is incredibly scuffed, and it's shocking to see no one really bring up how bad it is. I-Frame sources are scarce. You have an awkward backstep with a lengthy cooldown. You have a shield that you can only use with one(1) weapon type. The shield blocks 100% of damage but has a stability bar that drains in around 3 hits. When the bar drains you can't block for 10-15 seconds. If you're reliant enough on the shield to see that happen you might as well put the controller down because you're about to get comboed to death. The last and most potent source are possessions. By attacking enemies  you build up stamina, and you can use that stamina to trigger highly damaging summon/transformation magic attacks that also have tons of i-frames. It's strange to see many comments talk about fun melee combat when the combat seems to be entirely balanced around pure mashing. I'm never really styling on an enemy or skillfully countering them. I'm just building stamina and mashing a possession before an enemy attacks. Speaking of enemies...

Enemy design in this game is also quite boring/bad. I'm sure you've noticed the game's collage-esque asset artstyle. While that can be sort of charming, what isn't is the resulting effects it seems to have on  animation/ clarity. So many attacks in this game have poor tells. Lot's of attacks where an enemy will do a "rear" animation, awkwardly repeat a few frames of this animation for like 2-3 seconds, and then just do one of their attacks. Like they could have 3 separate attacks, but all three will start with the same rearing animation loop and then you just have to pay attention to particle effects to guess what attack they might do. Sometimes it's clear and many other times it isn't. Also, because this is an anime game there's tons of particle effects that completely obscure what the enemies are doing. So even if you can accurately read and evade an enemy, in actual gameplay when you're fighting a room full of them you won't be able to dodge at all. This makes every encounter boil down to safe/ranged pokes into possession spam. I really need you all to realize that possession spam IS the game. There are no interesting combos, or exciting defensive counterplay. The game is building up stamina to spam these moves. 

Boss design seems to be even MORE scuffed with bad hitboxes, and more complex patterns that don't suit the rigid control of the MC, but as i'm only at chapter 3 I need to play more to say something more concrete.

Finally the story. As I'm only on Chapter 3, I can't really speak on this. I've seen hints of strange/degen writing but none of the major ??? scenes yet. Story seems quite tropey and big on obvious twists. Many cases of "this is your TRUE identity" or "MC wakes up in realistic dream to meet important NPC" (btw what the actual hell is the MC's name... is he just unnamed???). World building seems... okay. There's pages you can pick up that talk about gods/towns and that's neat. As for what happens in the actual game though I'm not too impressed. That being said I do think the main story is interesting at the moment. There seems to be hints of some sort of greater force monitoring the astlibra scales and foreshadowing conflict with them. Speaking of the scales, they're a time travel macguffin so get ready to see some confusing plot holes.  

All in all, the game is still kind of fun. The main grind loop is fun it's just when the grinding gets interrputed by bosses/difficult enemies and you actually start dying you realize the game really isn't all that.

Me, and lots of other people: "how do you avoid getting hit?"

You keep playing. You unlock defensive abilities, and you learn how to use magic I-frames to avoid damage. But the real answer? You dont REALLY avoid getting hit. 

The game isn't about taking zero damage. It's like Dark Souls. You learn to take exactly enough damage to not die. The first 3-4 hours is about learning how to upgrade/purchase items to stay ahead of the curb. And how to take just enough damage so you don't die.

When you run into the Skeleton (simple enemy) in the beginning of the game, it's not about DODGING, it's about how you place yourself to avoid the occasional hit, but probably MORE about the fact that there's 10 items you could have unlocked before that point. None of them are great, but all of them unlock attributes upon mastery.

This is not a perfect game. It's a pretty good game that expects you to deal with the fact that you're powerless for a couple hours. After those couples hours? You're not powerful, you're just not weak anymore. And if you find yourself in a spot where you're weak - you probably need more basic items mastered. Grind.

This game is a 10/10 if you will spend the time to unlock and master things. It's a 7/10 if you spend a little extra time grinding, and get a few unlocks. It's a 2.5/10 if you just want to pick it up, and run through the game like it's no big deal.

Personally, it's about a 6.5/10. Pretty good. Frustrating at more than 1 point. The story has been enough to drag me along though, for sure.

138326683.review:
tl;dr - High recommend for any JRPG or ARPG fans. Surprisingly solid story with some satisfying combat + RPG systems, as well as an absolute banger of a soundtrack. 

This one really surprised me. I don't recall any fanfare around this game releasing, and had no idea there was a web-based version to begin with. This game is the product of 15 years of development total, and it definitely feels like a passion project. Gameplay is very reminiscient of SOTN-style Metroidvanias, but your progression comes from all of your passives and equipment rather than new world-traversal techniques. Make no mistake that this is first and foremost a JRPG, so the game plays out -very- story heavy and mostly linear. Minor exception being the completely optional farming / item hunting for achievements that you can do between chapters. Nothing in the game is overly tedious to farm, and I was able to get 100% achievements with minimal farming after the final boss with a total playtime of around 47 hours according to Steam. The story itself is well-done, and although it foreshadows certain elements a bit too hard, there are a good amount of genuine twists and turns along the way to keep you guessing. There is unfortunately a pretty consistent amount of fan-service in both dialogue and a few character designs, but being a JRPG it's to be expected.

The art is good though nothing particularly mind-blowing; it has a bit of an old-timey feel like you're a new gamer whose friend recommended them a SNES-era game, and for that it's got some charm to it. It doesn't try to be anything crazy, but for how long of a game is, the fact that there are essentially no recolored assets is commendable. The designs of the enemies and bosses are really cool, and do a good job of keeping things from getting stale by throwing some unique encounters at you throughout.

The boss fights themselves are challenging but very fair. I played on Hard (difficulty 3 of 5) and there were no major roadblock type bosses. Some of them get a little projectile heavy, but you have multiple tools to deal with this including i-frame during spells, the ability to destroy all enemy projectiles when you cast a spell, a generous dodge, and blocking. Both melee and magic-based playstyles are viable, and respeccing is incredibly simple / affordable to encourage both experimentation and per-fight changes. This is especially useful in the arena mode (preset encounters with stipulations like "don't get hit" or "don't use items"). You can definitely farm and get very overpowered, and there's a nice sense of progression from "dying to level 1 slime" to "screen-wiping invincible god" if you put enough time in. 

Lastly, the soundtrack for this game is nuts. It's really unfortunate that the official soundtrack isn't purchaseable, because there are some tracks that bat way above the average you'd expect for a relatively unknown game like this. Jazzy songs with female vocals, somber piano and strings tracks for emotional moments, boss fight tracks that would fit in to an EDM festival, rock tracks that evoke Mega Man X's soundtrack, and even a Halloween rap. The game is 100% worth playing through for the soundtrack alone, and I found my list of "no wait, this track's my favorite" growing with every chapter. 

All in all, a ridiculously good game made all the better by its criminally underpriced price tag. Any fan of ARPGs or JRPGs owes it to themselves to give this a shot. For everyone else: it has a free demo so you have no excuse to not at least give it a try, and if you find yourself having even a little bit of fun with the combat, 100% buy it; you won't regret it.

If you like action RPGs, I cannot stress enough how good this game is.

Lots of equipment and abilities to unlock plus accessible respeccing means you can always play in a way that works for you. It also means there is plenty of content to keep you occupied.

Save points are frequent and provide full a restore, but also respawn enemies. They're great if you want to grind, but they also don't get in the way if you just want to keep moving.

If you die before a story beat or just don't care about the plot, this game has one of the best skip systems I've ever encountered. Pretty much every cutscene or dialogue box in the game can be skipped.

The story can be hard to follow at times and won't be everyone's cup of tea, but the character development is pretty good and the cast is varied if a bit tropey.

The graphical style is a bit strange, especially if you just look at screenshots, but it comes together in a cohesive way.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game. It's rare for me to 100% or achievement chase for a game, but I did both for Astlibra Revision.

137600274.review:
What an absolute masterpiece of an experience. One of the rare times where the phrase "greater than the sum of its parts" is not only applicable, but is a gross understatement. I completed all achievements in 65 hours and I was very surprised at how much content this unassuming indie title has for you. 

The basic premise is that it is a 2D JRPG "Metroidvania" with fast and smooth combat. When I say "Metroidvania", I don't mean Symphony of the Night, where it is one (two) giant map. This is more like Order of Ecclesia, where there are several smaller maps that aren't physically connected. 

The visuals are both great and also lacking. The sprites are all wonderful, though I wish the animations had more frames. In the middle of combat you don't notice the frames of animation that the sprites have in the slightest and everything moves fluidly as the actual FPS is stable. The biggest complaint I have visually are some of the background and foreground environment sprites have clear lines so you can tell exactly how it is all tiled together. Again, in the heat of combat you will not notice it at all. That being said, everything looks cohesive and nothing ever seems like it was designed and created for another project and just pasted into the game without care. 

The combat is awesome. It is fast and simple on the surface but also has depth to it. You will have a bad time if you are just mashing the attack button and not much else. You must utilize the offensive and defensive skills you learn along the way. Possession skills are great and eventually become very overpowered once you master how to fight. It becomes so fun once you get into the groove of it all that you will want to take the time to max out the exp on all of the weapons, shields, and armor... and it won't feel like a chore at all. 

The RPG mechanics for leveling stats, crafting, weapons, armor, shields, Karon magic, the Force board, Possession skills, Libra system, Item boards, and enhancing your equipment keeps you busy and you always feel like you're making progress and improving. Each aspect is straightforward on its own and in conjunction with the other systems forms a tight web of character progression not seen often enough. This game respects your time in ways most others in the JRPG/RPG realm fail to by having several ways to respec almost at any time. There are tons of free places to do it in town or at mokyun shops. From shops you can buy respec potions so you can do it anywhere. It is a nice touch. 

The story is very JRPG but man did I care about it. I didn't really expect that going into it based on the demo and screenshots of the game, as well as other reviews that suggested it was all over the place and what not. I didn't think so at all. I don't normally care about story too much as a lot of times it appears to be just a means to an end, kind of thought up on the spot to justify mechanics of the game, but that isn't the case here. I was very invested in the goings on of everyone. Almost brought to tears, empty pit in my chest levels of invested in the story. 

The music is done by a bunch of different artists and it is basically all wonderful. There was some random rap song in one optional room I didn't care for. On the other hand, the third area music was done by the legendary S.S.H. and it shreds. Other styles are present as well and it really fits so much better than you would think. I'm going to be listening to a few of these tracks for a very long time down the road. 

Some things that you need to do to progress the game aren't totally communicated well to you, though that is most likely due to the translation. If you pay attention and don't skip cutscenes or conversation, you'll probably be able to figure out what you need to do 90% of the time. There were a couple spots where what was needed seemed sort of obtuse and I didn't really seem to understand how I was supposed to glean what to do from the story or conversations with NPCs or environmental clues. Though when you bring up the menu it will give you direction on what you're supposed to be doing overall, but again, a couple times that wasn't any help at all. 

Trust me when i say this game is great. I don't ever write reviews. I am sacrificing sleep to write this because I thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game. This is much better than so many AAA big budget RPGs and it was just a labor of love from one guy. That passion is palpable through out the entirety of this game. 

This is a steal at full price, if it ever goes on sale, do no hesitate to pick it up.

The story provides and engaging and nuanced take on the old time travel formula with multiple endings possible. The characters are likable and almost all of them have depth and some form of a backstory. 

Game play is excellent if you like side scrolling hack and slash, metroidvania-esque item hunting, and loot farming type of games. The controls aren't extremely precise but the hit boxes feel fairly accessible so the game play isn't hindered. The challenge remained consistent on hard mode although by postscript endgame, I was severely overpowered. That's more a testament to how satisfying the grinding/loot farming was than a critique on the balance of the game.

If I absolutely had to complain about something, it's that this game reeeealllly leans into tropes of traditional gender roles, damsels in distress, and casual misogyny for humor. Not really anything that we're not all used to and probably has a lot to do with the fact that this game has been 14 years in the making (!!!) but just seems like we can progress beyond that at this point.

137112486.review:
Astlibra Revision (ALR). I remember the first time I saw pictures and videos of this game on Steam, I thought "Mmh. Looks stiff". And now that I've played it for quite some time, I have to admit: I still think the same. But on the other hand, I had a lot of fun. And this dichotomy might be at the center of Astlibra, a really fun game plagued by some technical/design flaws.

First of all, I have to talk about not the animations but the battles. They are fun. And they're also flawed. To begin with, ALR is a very dynamic action RPG where you will jump everywhere and hit everything that comes your way. You can do some combos, use some magic skill, do some special moves like an uppercut that also works as a launcher, etc. When looking at it quickly, you could say it's a kind of character action game. You do a combo, launch your enemy, jump, continue your combo in the air and finish it with a magic skill.

But here's the first flaw of this game and the biggest one too, the total absence of hitstun. Every enemy can and will hit you in the middle of a combo, even when they're launched and you're in the air with them doing an air combo. Second flaw, the absence of readability. The game is filled with particles effects, each of your hits will hit 2 or 3 times, there are often multiple enemies on the screen so that's why it can be hard to know what's going on. A lot of time, you'll get hit by something and wonder what touched you. By the end of the game, enemies will hit very hard while the screen will look somethign straight out of a bullet hell, so you'll get hit multiple times by something you didn't see coming and lose 1/4 of your life for each hit. In the end, the combat system is the biggest flaw of the game.

One other flaw are the controls. They aren't bad, they are even responsive. No, the problem comes from the manipulations. You have to push a direction and a button to activate a special move, but in the heat of the action, it's not rare to do something else, because of how similar some moves are. One example is the possibility to launch your weapon and the launcher. To do the launcher, you have to hold the attack button and press up. To launch your weapon, you have to hold the attack button, then release it. Now, if you want to launch your weapon upward, you can see how problematic that can be.

About the controls, there's two schools in action games: manipulations and cooldowns. Historically, arcade/console games use mostly manipulations to allow you to do special moves (Street Fighter, Guardian Heroes, etc.), while pc games use cooldowns (Diablo). Here, strangely, even though the game plays clearly like a console game and some special moves need a manipulation, some of them also have a cooldown. I guess in this particular case, it's a matter of personal taste but the game should get rid of all cooldowns to allow a more fluid gameplay.

The hitboxes also need to be adressed. It's not a game breaking problem but sometimes, you'll get hit even though you thought were out of range. One other problem with the hitboxes is how the game seems incapable of handling diagonals. If there is a slope and you run on it, your character will fall. So, every slope is in reality some kind of stairs. On the other hand, that means your character can't run towards the top of a slope, you'll have to jump.

But ALR is good. It's not a technically exceptional game, the animations are really limited, the graphics are strange with a style that use realistic background and anime characters. However, what it lacks in the technical department, it makes up for it by giving the player a lengthy game (60 hours with a lot of griding) with a lot of content and secrets, multiple endings (sadly, only the true ending gives you an achievement), a great soundtrack (with some vocaloid here and there apparently), attaching characters and a story that is "basic" for a JRPG but still interesting, if you know some of the clichés that comes with the territory. It should be noted that tropes common in shounen manga are present (like an onsen sequence for example) with some jiggles physics to boot.

There is something that I also should adress right now. The game is described as a metroidvania and it's absolutely not one. You can go back to previously visited area, you can unlock skills that will let you reach new areas but those are just for items. You won't go back to a previous area to unlock a whole new one. In the contrary, ALR is a pretty "linear" game: you only progress forward.

Like I said, Astlibra Revision is a good but flawed game, it's even a great one. But I had to point out those glaring flaws though, especially its battles. But those, in the moment to moment gameplay, are also fun. In the end, this game is clearly an indie, a game with a lot of heart and some obvious limitations. You should also know before buying that it can require some grind if you want a seamless experience. There's also a post-game that I stopped playing quickly - but it exists.

Completely blown away by this game. Utterly enraptured. I didn't want it to end. 

Combat was always an absolute blast. Well-tuned difficulty aligned perfectly with an expected and gratifying grind. Constant twists in the story to match equally compelling character growth systems. I want to call this _THE_ sidescroller RPG experience. 

Thank you KEIZO for a game I'll never forget. 

---

Getting into this game was so fascinating for me. ASTLIBRA evokes an air of nostalgia surrounding perhaps a respected sleeper PC-98 game, one that you've only ever seen on the periphery of game lists. A game always just out of reach but always lauded whenever mentioned... a remake of a game for another day, maybe. The art, animation, and overall design experience lend themselves [i]so[/i] well to this feeling, as if you're playing something utterly classic and uncannily familiar. This makes ASTLIBRA feel like a triumphal love-letter to the genre, obfuscating itself as a hidden lodestone. As you play you'll learn it sets a new mark, surpassing expectations set by its forebears.  

Gameplay was consistently engaging and rewarding. Always new techniques to try out after grinding for mastery and equips through each new zone, culminating in zany, creative abilities and combos that allow for a surprising range of builds. I recommend playing on at least Hard, since the grind makes itself worthwhile without becoming overbearing. There are some difficulty spikes around bosses-- some early ones being absolute HP sponges-- but as you experiment with your various options and find patterns you start to see how the game is really played. Hint: Possession skills give i-frames. 

I said earlier that the story is compelling- and it is, if you have a ounce of soul- but take this with a grain of salt... as seasoning, rather than skepticism. The translation [i]is[/i] pretty hard, yeah, especially at first. The vast majority of the game is extremely well translated at this point, but there are still some moments with typos, syntax, or strange idioms that stand out. Personally, this is a pinch of that aforementioned salt: just part of the experience of doujin/fan translated media, lending strongly to ASTLIBRA's authentic feeling. The charming episodic openers make it clear that this game was formed chapter by chapter in its original doujin publishing online and make for excellent stylistic bookends. ASTLIBRA retains a lot of sentiment this same way through its storytelling: narratives and plot spectacle shenanigans that wouldn't be out of place in a LN or anime, moments of sudden levity that strike from nowhere, and an ambient level of horniness (providing much of said levity) that matches any given classic shounen. "Forgivably horny" is the term I've been throwing around. Wrap your expectations within this package and you'll be a very happy camper. 

The music selection and placement throughout the story are top-tier, and it makes me wince that we probably won't get a compilation for easy direct access. "Wintering Ezo Red Fox," "Go When," "Black Tears and Lives to Protect," and especially "Relic of Agunamonita" are all living rent-free between my ears now and forever.

The heart, dedication, and compassion put into this game by its developer are entirely evident, and he deserves every last ounce of praise we can give. KEIZO, you can have my "Love," specifically the one Porin found on the ground for me. That one was cool.

EDITED REVIEW: Well, I suppose this is one instance where I have to eat crow (heh, apologies to the little buddy in this game). To use the Shaq meme, "I have to apologize, I wasn't really familiar with your game."

Have I changed my mind about the critiques I mentioned? No, the translation still hurts the game and the graphics are still somewhat underwhelming. However, after finishing it and experiencing it firsthand, I can say without reservation that the story is SO good that even despite the terrible translation it carries the game and makes it a must-play. I don't want to spoil anyone but it really is the sort of thing you have to experience for yourself, just hearing about it doesn't do it justice. It's been a long time since I actually felt emotionally attached to a game's characters, but this one actually did it, and I got tears in my eyes during one of the climactic fights (you guys will know the one). So yeah, I'm turning this review from negative to positive and encouraging everyone who reads it to forget my earlier churlishness and buy this game. Just try to ignore the bad translation (so far, hopefully they'll patch it soon).

A couple other reasons for a positive revision. First, when you get a wider variety of combat skills, it really does become pretty satisfying and engaging. The fact that there are so many mistranslations (for instance, the description for one crucial skill says it recovers ST when it actually recovers HP) hurts it, but like I said above, they should fix it with a new translation soon. Second, while it's still not genuine Vanillaware quality, some of the boss sprites, especially near the end, do look super cool. Third, the music is MUCH better than I gave it credit for at first. Most of it is taken from free stuff, but by the end you can tell the dev became an expert at choosing good songs, as a lot of the themes and event music are absolutely perfect and wonderful to listen to, I especially love the Belkade late-game themes.

Finally, more than anything else, there's one primary reason I revised my review to a positive one: One of the devs themselves (specifically the publisher) took my concerns to heart. In general, I'll almost always support a dev if they acknowledge my suggestions and make changes even if I'm dissatisfied with a game at first. I did this with They Must Be Billions, didn't like it at first but changed my negative review to positive after they released a patch making the game less annoying and adding more content. The publisher, WhisperQ, acknowledged my complaints with the translation and has mentioned there'll be a patch to fix it soon! So I'm definitely all about supporting folks who want to improve even if they've made a mistake, and I can't wait for the revamped translation so I can enjoy the game as it was really meant to be played. I now encourage all of you to buy it, support the devs, and join me!

First solidly negative review I've written in a while, but while I really tried to give this game a fair shot, it has too many problems for me to recommend it. Despite some extremely good points--15 years of effort, an absolutely massive, in-depth combat system and art from Shigatake, one of the Vanillaware guys--the flaws of this game make it impossible for me to recommend or even justify paying 20 dollars for. Specifically, like I said, it has one of the most in-depth combat systems you can find anywhere, but the atrocious translation hurts it severely. There's a huge amount of skills to unlock, many of which are absolutely crucial, but mistranslations or outrightly incorrect translations make it very difficult to tell which skills you actually need--you need to use some of the guides friendly people on Steam have provided, which isn't acceptable for a professionally produced game. The control mapping is also absolutely terrible. Thankfully, you can change some of the more annoying button mapping, like the dash and enter room buttons being the same, but there's a shield bash move that makes some of the platforming segments nearly impossible when it activates when you don't want it to, and you can't disable that without either not using shields at all (locking yourself out of a pretty significant number of abilities and gameplay choices) or going through a bizarrely arcane method, one again described by some good steam folks. Like I also mentioned, the art from Shigatake is very nice, but unfortunately you won't find the delightful backgrounds of Odin Sphere or 13 Sentinels in this game, because the great artist just did character portraits--the backgrounds, terrain, etc. looks like cheap freeware fare. The plot, from what I've gathered, is actually relatively compelling despite how it starts off as not a basic riff off an old-school Ys style platformer, but again, the poor translation cripples its impact. As much as I wanted to love this game I cannot in good conscience recommend it, though if my refund request doesn't go through since I've beaten the first chapter, I might play through it some more if I'm stuck with it after this. We'll see if I change this review.

135219660.review:
Holy crap, what a game. I guess I'll start by saying I love this game and I'll probably play everything this developer continues to make for the foreseeable future. That being said it also has a LOT of issues. 

The game straight up lies to you. There's multiple points in the game where it tells you "this is the final battle" and then the game continues to give you more missions after that final battle. And not like Super Ultra, secret post final boss missions. The game literally just casually continues like it didn't just tell you it was about to end. It's like that awkward friend that says goodbye, and then continues to hang out for hooours. Which wouldn't be as bad, if that friend didn't also continue saying goodbye throughout the night. 

The game lying to you is made even worse by the fact that there's a lot of mistranslations too, so not only is the game lying, but you're also being given just completely untrue information. 

And I understand this next point comes with the territory of making a game centralized around Time Travel as a theme, but Astlibra really takes it too far. Killing off and resurrecting characters multiple times really desensitizes you and trivializes any sense of tragedy. There was one character that died in a bad timeline because I made a bad choice. I struggled tooth and nail to save her, and was so relieved to have her back, only for her to die again in another timeline, and then revived again because I went even further back in time and did something that undid it all. Again. This doesn't happen once, twice, or even just three times. It happens a LOT to multiple characters. And it's a shame, because I actually cared a lot about every single character that was introduced, until they were killed and resurrected for the fifth time. 

The combat is fun, but only if you unlock everything. And I cannot fathom why the developer hid some of the combat mechanics as secrets. One of the early game skills you have to really go out of your way to unlock is a jump slash. And if you miss this secret skill, you essentially go through the whole game not knowing that air combos exist, because you have no way of launching enemies into the air. It really feels like a bad oversight to have splintered these essential skills off as secrets. And it wouldn't be so bad if the secrets were easy to find, but a lot of them are really obtuse. 

And the last thing I'll touch upon is that the game has too many twists. There were several versions of the story I liked, but each of those stories then got undermined by another new twist that revealed that was never the real story all along, all along. 
For example, there's a "main story ending" that is probably one of the more incoherent and straight up idiotic endings I've ever seen. But then there's a New Game+ that is supposedly just extra content, but at some point it continues to main story and fixes the ending by making it all actually just a dream. I accept this, because the main story ending was REALLY bad, but it really leaves you scratching your head if the NG+ content is canon then, because it specifically refers to itself as just extra content. This goes back to what I was saying about the game straight up lying versus misinformation. 

Overall, I enjoyed the game and recommend it, but expect to be left very conflicted. There's simultaneously so much good and so much bad, I'll be very surprised to find anyone that just straight likes or dislikes this game.

134769004.review:
What can I say? I didn't expect much, but it was a nice ride. The game is simple, but the music, boss variety, design is absolutely gorgeous. The story was kind of cheesy, but note that this was made for more than a decade, so if you're ready to expect a 10-year-old style theme, delivery, you're in for a nice, warm ride.

EDIT: I'd also like to point out that about 40% of players finished this game, with about 30% finishing the extra story. Most AAA "Overwhelmingly Positive" games out there do not have this kind of completion rate. This is one solid evidence of how great this game is.

PROS:
- Addictive combat. While it can be simplistic, it is very satisfying in a sense. It's not as pretty as other modern games of its kind though.
- GREAT progression. Character progression is very, very good. If you take a little bit of time to grind A LITTLE, you can pretty much reach and grab all missables as you progress through the story.
- Railroaded, but you can revisit other stages. So you missed an item from a stage? You can go ahead and go back to it after you finish your current "chapter".
- No missables. In connection to bullet 2, this game very much respects the player's time. If I miss something from a stage, I can go back. Before I finished the game, it warned me that I can no longer go back if I progress, so there is always a clear indicator if I'm about to miss some stuff.
- Finish the game now, or play more. You can finish the game with a "good" ending, but you can play more. I'm not going to spoil it, but this game is about 50-60h long storywise.
- Endearing and engaging story. It's a 10-year-old theme, and you can see how the cheesy interactions supports how long this took to deliver. But it's very endearing, heartwarming, and the twists and plot, while not over-the-top, are very good.
- Very, VERY good character development. Each character is very much developed properly with their own backstory, and not just simple backstories, but intertwine through your own to build theirs. They are VERY much fleshed out, and they are just not some lame background. You will learn to remember and appreciate each character, not just because they have their own motivations, but their story doesn't end when they met you, their story goes on as yours does.

CONS:
- Animations are limited. Animations themselves, like joint twists and physics look like the old Flash games. But they are not that bad, just looks old.
- Bad translations. While the translations were somehow fixed in a lot of places, there's still some awkward translations in a lot of spots, and line breaks where it isn't necessary. Some of the jokes and parody can't be appreciated to their full potential because of these awkward translations, but the story still overpowers these bad translations because it's really nice.
- Bad translations on skills. Some skills, called KARON can be VERY confusing. This is also due to translation, but the information that some of the skills give are extremely unclear in what they do.
- Why do I have to keep watching the intro movie each time I finish a chapter?
- Why does the grow board give infinite keys on the very last and bottom node if there's nothing to use it for?
- Some few imbalances, but these do not make you OP or gimp you, it just feels it could've been fleshed out more, but the developers didn't because there wasn't really anything you could use it for.
- Lack of "infinite replay" endgame. Because of the design philosophy of the developer, the endgame is revolved and heavily tied to the story as well. You can grind a little to max out everything, but basically the "infinite replayability" is tied to a 4-level procedurally generated dungeon that has 3 variants of themes. Not a big problem, because this game wasn't designed for that. It's great the developers tried to incorporate something for people who can't get enough of the game though.

All in all, this game was worth every penny. There is great progression, very good variety of enemies, bosses (more then Elden Ring or Breath of the Wild), and the best feature that I personally like, VERY VERY good character development.

Buy it full price. It's worth every penny you drop, and don't let the limited animations in combat disappoint you. Play for a few hours and it'll grow on you and you'll suddenly find yourself trying to finish it and unlock everything!

I enjoyed a ton of aspects about this game, and while it isn't the perfect game it does many things really well :)


Gameplay 9/10
I felt like the movement in this game felt so fun especially once you get more upgrades/levels. Gets a lot more challenging when you play at a higher difficulty and you master the movement. I really enjoyed the leveling mechanics and looting as well. There are a lot of weapons you can choose from and upgrade, and each weapon has its own uniqueness to it which felt nice. Also have to mention that there are a plethora of difficulties to choose from so it doesn't matter if you are the most casual gamer or extreme. I will say I played on hard which felt very challenging for myself, and I don't think I would have the patience to play on the 2 higher difficulties lol

Music 8/10
Really enjoyed the music, I felt like every song fit very nicely with what was going on in the game. I thought it was funny how later on in the game they started to use more vocaloid, shoutouts to Hatsune Miku lol. If you are a vocaloid/dnb/jrpg style music fan you will enjoy the OST pretty easily. Some dubstep wubwub in the ost which I'm not the biggest fan of but it was fine. PS I think there is over 100 tracks? There's a ton of music.

Visuals 9/10
I noticed a lot of people in the reviews are saying this game looks ugly? I don't think those players made it very far in the game because there are a lot of really nice looking backgrounds/scenery, awesome looking bosses and some unique style animations. Maybe this style of visual is not for them I guess. A lot of scenery in the game looks fantastic especially if you can make it to the later stages of the game (final boss fight for example was one of the sickest looking things I've seen in gaming). In terms of 2D visuals this is a very nice looking game.

Replayability 8/10
I'd say this game definitely has some decent replay value especially in the post game where they add a lot of roguelike elements like randomized dungeons with a new loot system where you can further upgrade your skills and weaponry to give you way more customization than you thought you already had before the post game story. For me personally I don't think I will come back to the game for quite some time because I felt like it was just so much grinding to 100% the game so it kind of wore me out but I could definitely see myself coming back to play again at some point. If you are a completionist I will admit it is a challenge, there is a lot of hard things to find and you have to do a lot of grinding but if you really like the game it will feel just right, maybe a bit overwhelming at times. 

Story 9/10
As many other reviewers said it definitely starts slow but it ramps up like crazy especially near the end, I was extremely invested in the characters and progression, always wanting to know what was going to happen next. KEIZO the dev definitely went hard with this story and you could tell a lot of their passion went into this story. You ever seen those commercials where you think it's over but then they are like "BUT WAIT, THERE'S MORE" THIS GAME HAS THAT WRITTEN ALL OVER IT LOL NOT GONNA LIE. A lot of times you think you are done there is way more to do, I swear the amount of "final boss" fights I thought would end the game did not end the game and there was always something else in the story popping up to keep it going. If you enjoyed the game enough to make it to the end of the main story I highly recommend doing the post game content because there is actually a lot more to the story after the game initially "ends"

Price 10/10
As far as pricing in the US the game is $24.99 I think that is perfectly acceptable for a game of this caliber. As you can see I have 100+ hours invested into the game and almost enjoyed every single minute of it. 

Overall 9/10
I noticed the game getting some flack in the negative reviews and I just don't think this is the kind of game for them. I must say don't click "Add to cart" blindly for the sole reason of seeing "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews. If you enjoy JRPGs, Metroidvania style games, 2D sidescrolling, looting/upgrade system, decent story telling etc this will be right up your alley.  

If you want a passionate game made by a passionate game developer this is the one. 

Thank you KEIZO and all involved. You gave me an experience in a game I will never forget about and I am looking forward to any future titles :)

Do I recommend this game ? Yes. 100% yes.

Now for the explanation. Gameplay spoilers ahead.

This game is a bundle of good ideas. You've got so many ways to improve your character. The weapons, shields and armors you get have a dedicated EXP gauge, and when it's maxed out, you get either a new passive that you can toggle in a separate menu or a boost of its stats along with a crystal. Said crystal is used to equip passives BUT if you equip the piece of stuff that gave you a passive, then you can equip the passive for free. Long story short, think FF9 or Tactics.

When you level up, you get 5 gems that you can allocate among HP, ATQ, DEF, MAG, SPD, LUC and ADA. The first 4 are obvious, SPD allows you to wield your weapons faster and to go further with your shield bash, LUC nets you more exp per enemy defeated as well as more loots of course. ADA, for adaptability, is a niche stat which allows you to make the breathing gauge last longer when your character is underwater. Basically, you never up it except when needed. In case you're worrying about a bad choice, don't fret, you can change the allocation at every level up as well as at a spot in the shops here and there.

At some point, you get a set of scales, on which you can put items from your inventory, granting you several effects, which work at best when the scales are, as a certain Marvel villain would say, perfectly balanced. As you advance, you'll get more scales, to put more items and activate more effects.

There's also a massive tree similar to FF10, in which you expend Force, a currency dropped by enemies, to earn more stats, as well as bonus crystals and pieces of stuff. The clever part is that it's blocked at several points, and you need to advance in the story to go further.

The gameplay is terrifyingly efficient, and once you've got a nice stuff, you mow enemies like there's no tomorrow.

The story is quite nice, with some plot twists. There are a few mistakes here and there, but nothing that would stop you from understanding the plot.

A little negative aspect would be that there are some "false choices", leading you to the main screen and making you load your game. Fortunately, the game is generous in the number of save points, and when such a choice is ahead, there's often a save point right before.

If you've read this all, congratulations, but... why are you still reading instead of playing this game ?

ASTLIBRA is a very good side-scrolling JRPG that can best be described as a mashup of everything ever. The graphic style of cobbled-together assets is incredibly charming, the effects are varied and bombastic and the game is as over-the-top in both plot and visuals as you would expect from a game of this genre. It plays incredibly fluidly and is highly customizable - one-handed weapon and shield, staffs, two-handed weapons, magic and so on. You can put force you gain from enemies into a kind of attribute sphere board, think FF-X, and level up weapons and armor. To describe every aspect of this game would probably make this review a bit too long, but all parts of the game fit together perfectly to create a very fun experience.

The game is a *bit* too long, which is especially owed to the additional  chapter which just essentially rehashes most of what you have already done, with only a few new things near the end, though the fun gameplay balances it out. Depending on your difficulty setting, the game can also get very grindy; I recommend Normal for a balanced but still challenging experience. Something that irritated me as well was that some bosses can get very cheesy or just have too much going on on the screen, resulting in some quick deaths; and restarting the boss battle immediately does not refill your consumables like in most other games, which can be frustrating. The game's story is the perfect mix of convoluted and engaging, but some of the dialogue suffers from some iffy translation errors and some of the more "adult" themes in this game made me raise an eyebrow or two.

Still, ASTLIBRA is a fantastic experience. It's fast-paced, fun JRPG goodness with plenty to do, and there is even a demo! And as a special mention, the soundtrack of the game rocks - it has rocking battle music, vocal rap tracks, dirty dubstep beats, heartfelt melodies and anything else you can imagine. You owe it to yourself to play this if you have even a remote interest in games like this.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Astlibra is quite unique, really hard for me to describe why it is so enjoyable to play. One of those games that you gotta play to get it I guess.

Accordingly I'll just do a quick breakdown of the game features. 

[h1]The good stuff[/h1]
The game is 2d side scrolling action game with a strong emphasize on character progression. A dedicated post would be required to give a in-depth explanation of all the various features related to character progression. So if you're into character building just know that the game has plenty to offer.

Do note that the game isn't a metroidvania, you go through the levels in a linear fashion, you do not need to come back later on (you can however if you wish, grinding or missed stuff for example). There are plenty of secrets to find though, even basic moves like dodging (back step) can be "hidden" for example. Keep your eyes peeled!

The battle system can seem button mashy but will become a lot more "tactical" the higher the difficulty and the more you progress through the game (do note that you can become quite OP during the post game).
Once I got a good understanding of the mechanics I really started having a blast.

Depending on the difficulty, the game expects you to grind moderately to heavily. However it's actually not that bad. You have plenty of reasons to do so and since the game is also an action skill based game, it give you an plenty of excuses to level up your skill as a player.

[EDIT:
As you can tell from the reviews, the game is [b]lengthy[/b]. There's really a lot of content especially for the genre. I didn't get "burned" but some people might. This here is no casual game].


[h1]The bad stuff[/h1]
The writing is really not to my liking, I find it be all over the place, messy, very convenient in some parts and quite hard to follow. It can be related to the very poor level of the English translation, quite expected from a JP inde one man project tbf. But still, it's barely above google translate.  Luckily you can skip cut scenes (there are loads of them btw).
A poorly translated story is one thing, but when it also impacts the better aspects of the game like skill descriptions, it becomes really annoying. 

Another reviewer said that the game had a bit of male fandom, I found it to be quite an elegant way to put it.  I personally found that some parts of the game had a distinctive pervy tone sometime worthy of a hentai doujinshi intro.
Not really about being prude or anything but more about being really embarrassed for the writer. Felt like out of place poorly worded teenager fantasies that don't add anything.
It's a jp thing though, dragon quest games have always been a bit "naughty" for example. So yeah [i]lost in translation[/i] for me I guess.

You'll probably have to resort to guides to progress through some parts of the game. It's sometime not really clear what you're supposed to do.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Despite the negatives, I still think the game (thanks to the gameplay) is a must play, fully deserving the overwhelming positive reviews.

Just wanted to end the review saluting the 15 years journey that KEIZO (the lone dev) took to make this game. Must have been quite a journey!

131925256.review:
游戏的剧情介绍是这样的：“村庄遭遇魔物袭击，主角和青梅竹马的爱努莉斯在巨龙的吐息中昏迷了过去。当他醒来时，面前只有一只会说话的失忆乌鸦，以及一个见不到其他人类的世界。为了找回爱努莉斯，主角和乌鸦在渺无人迹的森林中探索了八年，终于寻找到了人类的踪迹……”

对味了！（低情商：品鉴太多；高情商：就是这个味）不管是塞尔达传说，还是勇者斗恶龙，还是其他的一些JRPG游戏，救人似乎是一个亘古不变的游戏主题。而上到《塞尔达传说：旷野之息》这样的神作，下到一些几十K的远古小游戏，每个游戏对于这个主题的诠释确是不一样的。

《神之天平》的剧情，以一人加一鸟的旅途为铺就，采用章节式的叙事手段，将主角跨越大陆寻人的故事切割开来，在神之天平的帮助下，善良且充满勇气的主角，不断与人相遇，予人救赎，在纷纷扰扰中完成自己的旅途和冒险。

JRPG的味道，不仅来自于剧情，也来自于其由装备、技能、天赋、法术等构成的传统RPG角色要素，和探索、收集、强化等构成的传统RPG玩法要素。

像隐藏起来需要解谜才能获得的宝箱，看不出来走到附近才能采集的资源，和藏在某个角落里的隐藏地图……每一个地方的设置都让人忆起当年在各种游戏上的“挣扎与磨难”，即使放到现在，也在游戏性上有着不错的内容体现。

游戏的装备方面，需要去获取装备才能使用一些魔法，这就要不断去完成各项任务、体验游戏各个内容。装备也是有熟练度的，熟练度升满，就可以不装备这装备就用对应的魔法。

另外要说的是，游戏在存档机制上也非常复古，需要找到存档点才能存档。

游戏的画面在经过高清化后，算是非常不错的，远处的雪山，近处的水和森林，质感都是比较不错的，看上去像是HD版的古典JRPG。不过，对于我的胃口来说还是有些不太满足，还是希望有更加精美的画面呈现。（对于这种高质量游戏，各方面的要求也高起来了）

横板动作的“牢笼”
横板动作游戏，最吃手感。有一个“牢笼”的说法，因为受制于2D平面，游戏开发者对于横板动作游戏，更喜欢用一些框架内的动作，而不是像3D一样天马行空的多方位动作效果。也就是说，2D横板动作游戏的技能动作，尽管看上去各个游戏之间会有差距，但总归还是那一套东西。

而本作因为走的是传统JRPG那一套，施放技能等等也都是老游戏的那味道，粗糙中带着一点快感。技能方面除了武器的平X和一些组合技，更多的还是类似于早些年跟《拳皇》一样搓键位的施放方式，这也是为了适应手柄局促的键位而做的妥协。

而基于这套古典味道浓厚的动作玩法，本作的打击感属于是横板动作游戏里面较不错的类型了。不管是平X，还是时停之后的技能施放，用横板做出不错的打击感，是非常不容易的，这点很难描述，还需要各位读者自己体验。

虽然小怪基本都是在群殴，但是本作大部分时候还是冲入怪堆，也就是BOSS阶段会有一些不错的机制体验。而BOSS由于是置放在背景平面，虽然机制各异，有着独特的应对打法，但是也显得像在打纸片。

要说的是，本作的打击感和打击特效真的挺一般的，所以导致游戏的打击判定，至少从现代的眼光看来，用华丽炫目来掩盖打击特效的不足，并不太行，基于游戏的画面呈现出来的古典质感，有些与时代相逆行了。

出类拔萃的音乐体验
对味的不仅是剧情和RPG要素，还有音乐。

虽然各个地方都没有提到游戏的音乐是谁做的，但是本作作为一款展现JRPG魅力的游戏，音乐的功底也是在的。

优缺点简要总结
+丰富可玩的剧情

+出类拔萃的音乐

+充实的RPG要素

-有些跟不上时代的打击特效

ASTLIBRA ～生きた証～ Revision Review
The best and the weirdest thing about Astlibra is that it feels, looks, and sounds like an artifact from the past; like a forgotten PS1/PS2 game. And in some sense, it really is — being mostly made by a single person over 15 years. It is one of the comfiest games I've played, with difficulty tuned to be just right (I beat the game on Hard), the grind being just long enough not to become dull, the progression giving you new things to look up to and think about often enough to keep the combat from turning stale, and the story always throwing curveballs to keep you on your toes and prevent you from guessing what's going to happen next.

In terms of gameplay, the closest comparisons I can draw are Dust: An Elysian Tail, and the Ys series. The former being a straightforward action platformer with a robust combat system. The linear structure and the fast-paced, action-oriented gameplay are rather refreshing in this age of endless roguelites and metroidvanias. The latter having a classic JRPG story about fighting against seemingly insurmountable odds to save your loved ones. After falling out of touch with modern JRPGs that either overload you with a dozen of proper nouns in the first hour and try to involve you in some political conflict; or simply being about a bunch of whiny school children (and often being very problematic about it) doing stupid things but still coming on top of incredibly incompetent adults this game's story is anime, but in a good way — in the same way as TTGL or DBZ is.

Astlibra starts slow in every sense of the word. The game begins with a lengthy cutscene (the textbox even warns you that the intro is long and absent of action), slow and simple combat, and a bare minimum of RPG progression. But over the course of 60-80h, it really ramps up, only dropping the tempo a handful of times, but never entirely stopping until the very end of the 3rd ending. What initially began as a search for your childhood friend turns into a time-travel adventure involving gods of inner and outer realms, multiple intertwined storylines, and a sizeable cast of major and episodic characters. A relatively slow and simplistic attack-and-block combat turns into an air-juggling and spell-slinging visual feast.
A basic STR/DEF/MAG RPG system expands multiple times, unlocking more and more ways to affect your character stats and abilities, including, but not limited to systems similar to NieR: Automata's Plug-in Chips, FF X Sphere Grid, and FF Tactics' Equipment abilities.

PS: I almost forgot to mention an absolute banger of a soundtrack, consisting primarily of a Vocaloid-infused drum and bass EDM tracks straight from '00-'10, with an occasional brostep thrown into the mix. While it might not be everybody's cup of tea, it definitely works well for the action and the story that it frames and deserves to be called one of the most daring soundtrack choices in my recent memory.

I bought this game after seeing a lot of people recommending it, even though I was a bit put off by the graphics, and I am so glad I did.

I think this game is an absolute masterpiece. I can think of no other word to describe it. Calling it a diamond in the rough would be doing it a disservice, because the only thing rough about it is the localization being just a little bit spotty at times (but never enough to be an issue, I have to stress).

The gameplay is fairly basic, but it evolves as you get further and you can customize your loadout a fair bit. In the beginning, your moveset is quite limited, but you will quickly find yourself unlocking more options that dramatically increase your versatility, as well as alter your approach to combat. One of the greatest strengths of the combat system in this game is that you can re-allocate your stats at will at zero cost at almost any point in time. If you want to be more tanky at the cost of your damage output, you can do that. If you want to have far more potent magic, but be squishy, you can do that. Want to make your attacks obscenely powerful at the cost of dying in one hit? You better believe you can do that. It offers an insane amount of freedom when it comes to how to approach any given fight, and I frequently found myself changing my stats and weapon loadout to better suit a new challenge.

The music, weirdly, is phenomenal. One of my favorite tracks in the game, I discovered, was a vocaloid track from almost a decade ago, which was pretty shocking. The variety of songs and how well they are used really caught me off guard, and there is a surprising amount of certified bangers included. If you had a vocaloid phase, or just listen to a lot Japanese music in general, you'll probably like a lot of the songs this game throws at you.

Graphically speaking, it's obviously not gonna win any awards, and the animations are a little on the stiff side, but your character's armor and weapon actually do affect how their sprite looks. Literally every single weapon and armor piece, and even some accessories, dramatically alter your sprite, which is a frankly absurd amount of effort to put in. I went through most of the game using sub-optimal gear just because I liked how it looked.

Lastly, I have to mention the story, and I have nothing but praise for it. I very rarely get invested in stories, but this one caught me hook, line, and sinker. I've ruined my sleep schedule staying up late to play this game because I just had to find out what happened next. I implore you to go in as close to blind as you can, so that nothing gets spoiled for you, because the twists and turns this rollercoaster of a story throws at you are genuinely some of the best I've seen in any video game, ever.

The sheer amount of content is also staggering, and it's all well-made. There are some instances of bosses being reused, but it was never distracting or even close to being a bother. I cannot stress enough just how much content is crammed into this game, and how it just keeps going and going long after I thought it would be over.



TL;DR: I love this game more than I can possibly express with words, and if you have even the slightest interest in this type of game (or even if you don't and are just feeling experimental!), you owe it to yourself to give it a try.
