[i]Do not forget: You are taking other people's treasure when protecting your own. If the Scale of Destiny favors a soul, it destroys the fate of another. Will you change this balance, or cast your eyes aside? Is it true that your choices bear no responsibilities? Is it true that you committed no crimes?[/i]

Do you ever know from the very moment a title screen hits you're about to play an all-time great? The PC-98 music hits, the moonlit background descends, and I knew instantly Astlibra was about to become one of my favorite games.

There's something to be said for the sheer freedom of expression allowed when one has absolute authority over their creative expression, especially in a culture like Japan routinely producing off-kilter ideas. Keizo is, like any good Japanese artist, fucking horny. You thought Takahashi was horny while directing Xenoblade 2? Nah, fam. Astlibra is plagued with scantily clad titty beasts. Plant monsters whose only censorship is her vines, floating bodies without appendages but no deficit of cleavage, goddesses whose battle armor is lingerie, [i]individual boob physics on each breast[/i], and a year's supply of juvenile sex humor you've seen in literally every ecchi you've ever watched. To really round off the sentiment, there's a traditionally JRPG colosseum-like arena with individual matches and one of those matches is titled "Harem" in which you have to slay every degenerate demon the game has ever thrown at you. Keizo is fucking horny.

Keizo is also, like any good Japanese artist, fucking [i]extra[/i]. This man has read his fair share of visual novels, clearly loves time travel, and probably threw every idea he ever had over its development time at the wall and performed mad science to fuse it all together. This design philosophy extends to the gameplay for sure, but I'll come back to that later, because there's a phenomenal story here if you can make sense of it all.

Time travel is fascinating; even when it's riddled with plot holes it's gotta be one of my favorite genres. There's not a lot of "meaningful" choices in Astlibra, but there are choices, you can make the wrong ones, and you will feel the weight of them. There's VN-style epilogue-like "dead ends" (not always bad endings, necessarily). But most importantly, Astlibra's central theme is its opening tagline: life is a series of choices, and every time you make a choice to help someone, to save someone, you hurt or lose someone else. You could have the literal tools of God in your hands with the ability to correct any history you saw fit, but the butterfly effect unfolds -- what will you lose in the process?

Chapter 7 really struck an emotional chord with me, one that all-time greats like Fullmetal Alchemist (2003) and Mahou Shoujo Madoka Magica have, when the price of obsession was made manifest. What are you willing to sacrifice for your obsession? I watched a dry comedy-drama called Russian Doll last year, also a time travel story, and a certain character described something they termed a "Coney Island moment": your one past decision where everything went to hell. You made one catastrophic decision, however inconsequential it seemed at the time, tugging the lynchpin that kept your entire life together, and the butterfly effect surely unfolds. Astlibra's thesis is thus: if you could reverse time and undo the "Coney Island moment," sacrificing all the bonds and memories you made in the process, would you, and could you live with the consequences afterward? So many ideas are thrown into the story & lore it can be difficult to untangle, and yeah, I'm pretty sure it's riddled with plot holes (although I'll note that by the end it *felt* like every loose end was resolved), but if you can untangle the mess and bask in the distinctly Japanese zaniness, it packs some serious emotional weight.

[i]If you choose one, you lose another. I made my choice by weighing my options on the Scales.[/i]

The over-the-top design philosophy is infused into the gameplay as much as the narrative. By the postgame there are four different progression systems, a wide variety of techs with near-infinite build options and the ability to respec whenever you want.  I finished the game on hard, and it was fucking hard. My final clock time -- getting 100%, including achievements -- was 61.5 hours, and Steam registers a playtime of 95 hours. There's idle time in there for sure, but that demonstrates well over a dozen hours of lost progress because there is no autosave and trash mobs can fucking rip you a new one. By chapter 5 or so, it's entirely practical to be dying within 3 hits.

Combat is visceral and the gameplay loop is crack. You will be [i]swarmed[/i] by fields of mobs as you hack 'n' slash your way through them, manipulating your iframes, guard gauge, cleverly hidden techniques, and Karon build to steamroll them as efficiently as possible, the gamepad rumbling in your hands with every slash, the frustration of playing what often feels like a 2D soulslike where every input matters, dying, dying dying to trash. Every chapter has its own equipment section with materials dropped by mobs only found in that chapter, accompanied by a super streamlined and super rewarding crafting system, making it sinfully easy to blow 5 minutes grinding for a few more mats to purchase that next available weapon. The game rewards grinding almost [i]too[/i] well.

The game's biggest flaw is how it reeks of early-to-mid 00s development. The gameplay loop is simple. The shitty ESL translation steals heavily from American idioms, like "using the John," in ways that just make zero sense within the setting's context, yet it's nonetheless nostalgic to a time of mediocre VN translations (Tohsaka's anus is defenseless), shitty anime subs, and downloading new episodes on BitTorrent then burning them to your DVD while posting screenshots of your ripped DVD collections on fan forums. The puzzles and platforming are excruciatingly retro; satisfying in their own way, but to solve them you have to think about them from a design perspective of a different era. You literally walk through glitches in the scenery to solve puzzles. Secret treasures in the game are well hidden in fucking pixel-sized green arrows, in the late game behind scenery, obstacles, and other hurdles making them, frankly, impossible to find unless you have a treasure guide up, and I absolutely recommend one to the side while playing. It's borderline cozy how there are virtually zero guides available online because it's so niche and playing it draws you into a real community; but there is a treasure guide, you should use it, and expect that otherwise, you will probably have to figure shit out on your own.

Everything comes into harmony to produce a grossly addictive game as I was propelled from literally the first 30 minutes to see the plot unfold, yearning to see the story's earliest and most harrowing mysteries resolved -- in most cases, far differently than I could have ever imagined.

[i]Struggling to regain what I lost made me lose everything else.[/i]

It's rare these days I can play a game and not levy a dumptruck load's complaints at it; I'm aging and I have a lot to bitch about it. A game's worth isn't so much defined by its flaws as it is how much its draws transcend those flaws. Astlibra is a gem. It's uniquely its own, there's so much to digest, and its creative expression is something you can really only get out of a game developed by one KEIZO for 16 years. The sort of poetic beauty to it all: the slice-of-life adventure of handling a new town's dilemmas every chapter; your guild master opening each chapter with a spine-tingling, heartrending summary of whose woes you must resolve; to see a VN-style opening theme at the end of EVERY FUCKING CHAPTER; all in a spacetime transcending romantic epic in pursuit of your first love. It's quirky, it's convoluted in a way only a JRPG could be, and it's beautiful. Go, my minions!

TL;DR: 
It's good and probably better in Japanese/Chinese - this is a public warning that you may not experience the 'overwhelmingly positive' vibes the other reviews give off. 

I'll chuck another 20 hours into it and we will see if the game re-defines my life, gives me a 6-pack and causes me to reach spiritual enlightenment like every other reviewer.

Vibe check follows: 
The systems in this game are incredibly deep and provide an incredible amount of customisation and depth which is a real shame because the weapons all feel very same-y. Heavy weapons feel exactly like magic weapons which feel exactly like shortswords. Combat appears flashy but is pretty shallow when you get into it. It boils down to find the summon with iFrames and abuse it while you spam whatever attack most efficiently builds up the summon gauge. The game feels like it's running at a lower FPS than it is because of all the slowdown when you hit an enemy with a weapon. Combat is like a vintage car, very pretty but you wouldn't want to drive it to work. 

Art wise, in screenshots it looks incredible - but the animations don't feel fluid. Most enemies and characters feel like cardboard cutouts stuck on ice-cream sticks. Character animations look like they were created with motion tween, 10 000 layers in Photoshop and blutac. Personal taste though - your mileage may vary.

People are really hype on the story - leading me to assume they played the game in Japanese or Chinese because some translations to English feel, for lack of a better term, constipated? (Like they're nearly right but still not quite there and it's really difficult to squeak it out and get a good flow going). The developers seem very active and responsive to issues with translation/community though so credit for that.

Truly a great game. If you like long action JRPGs and collecting equipment you will love this game.

Pros:

- story

- tons of equipment and skills to collect

- a lot of enemy variety and plenty of bosses

- music is really exceptional

- long (70h+)

- plenty of options for builds and variables to play with

- only 1 missable achievement (play the game on hard or higher)

- arena challenges (mostly normal battles but there are some dps checks and a bit of a puzzle fights too)

- you can skip cutscenes

- bossfight checkpoints between boss phases (with 1 exception for some unknown reason, maybe an oversight)

- situational humor, no modern day politics or meme/celebrity references

- over 100 save slots for your game saving needs

Neutral:

- if you are underleveled you will be 1 shot, if you are overfarmed you will just steamroll. I played the game on Hell difficulty which is next to last and honestly it wasn't so bad. Last difficulty makes the enemies too spongy for my taste for most of the game and Hell was perfect for me (there are like 3 or 4 lower difficulties too and you can always go lower but not higher)

- ability scrolls are hidden in the world (there are some ESSENTIAL combat skills that make this game so much better, hiding them isn't the best idea imo)

- a lot of cutscenes and reading (no voiceovers)

- a lot of time in the menus

- nostalgic feel, it plays like an "old" game so you have to think like you are playing an "old" game. For example, if you want to use an item on an object in the wold like a key on a locked gate you have to go into your inventory, select the key and use it.

- backstep instead of dodge forward but on the other hand shields are very strong in this game + you can always quickly turn around and "backstep forward", it just needs getting used to (there is a skill to make it into a forward dodge but you get this skill mod in postgame so it is waaaay to late for that)

- when you die you have to load your last save so you know, you lose everything you gathered up and done to the point of your demise (which is a great incentive to not die)

Cons:

- the further you progress the more flashy abilities you have, same goes for enemies and sometimes it is impossible to tell what the hell is going on during those massive bossfights because it's all overlapping

- solutions to some problems the game presents are mostly reasonable and were in one way or another mentioned along the way but this one part where you have to fill a huge jug with water so the STONE would float up to the surface is so mind boggling I would have never guessed wth I was supposed to do

- berserk skill breaks the game (3x damage but 1 hp), you can just turn skills on and off without any consequences and it seems to be a solution to many difficulty related problems people have, just turn berserk on when boss is "broken" or when  the window is open and turn it off the second you feel threatened, repeat to win ez. In other words, there is easily available cheese in the game.

- when you restart a boss fight from the "bossfight checkpoint" it doesn't give you back your consumables that you have used so better stock up before bosses

130849854.review:
Now before I start let me say I've played a lot of RPGs. I've quite literally learned how to read and write because of RPGs with the original Final Fantasy weaning me on letters and it only escalated from there. So I've played a lot of games across every flavor of "RPG (JRPG, SRPG, TRPG, ARPG, DRPG, etc). With that out of the way.

Astlibra is one of the better games I've played in the last decade. Though not without it's faults, it's a pretty quality experience from start to finish. For the most part.

[b] Story [/b]
To go more in depth. The story is sometimes predictable, sometimes completely insane, all parts neat to watch unfold. There's a decent amount of tropes played to comedic effect and the story doesn't always nail it's delivery (particularly at the end end game)  but for the most part it's well enough to follow through. 

[b] Combat [/b]
The combat is good. For an action RPG it's pretty high up there. The skill system letting you summon different spirits to assist combat as well as multiple special action the player themselves can engage in, once you get your upgrade and the combat gets going it REALLY gets going. The only downside is that towards the end game many larger skills summon creatures large enough to block your view of bullets which can become a substantial problem.

[b] Customization [/b]
The game avoids many of the pitfalls of all upgrades just being different flavors of starts towards the same end build. There are so many ways to build out your character with different skills to use, abilities to equip, weapons to use, and items to work around. The game has layers on layers of how to work on your character until the super end game.

[b] Presentation [/b]
I was originally turned off of the graphics of the game for all of about 5 minutes. But it takes all of 5 minutes to start appreciating  the games aesthetics and how it designs it's worlds and monsters to the point that a change anywhere wouldn't feel adequate. Good overall design and aesthetics.

[b] Difficulty  [/b]
I'm going to have to replay the game on impossible. That said on hell the games difficulty curve is one of my sore spots. At the start of the game you'll do relatively very little damage. Towards the midpoint of the game you are an unstoppable juggernaut that soaks hits with ease while effortlessly powering through most fights. Due to the overabundance of items you can carry, the rule "if it doesn't one shot you it doesn't matter" applies here. If the attack isn't enough to end you, you can full heal shortly after and continue with the fight. Sometimes that requires steps (like becoming invulnerable by using skill) but it still applies.

The game is well balanced until Chapter 8 but when the difficulty drops it REALLY drops and it never really recovers.

[b] sound [/b]
This games sound phenomenal. Not only is the music and selection fantastic, the sound effects and UI sounds are also fantastic. This is an understated aspect many times but UI elements need good sound design as well for something you're going to menu through countless times over your entire game. The game nails it. Great UI sounds. Great combat sounds. You'll instantly know what's happening by the sound alone. Not many games can properly succeed at this. 


As stated the game does a lot right. There's only a few cons which I'll list briefly:
[list]
    [*]No way to refight most bosses
    [*]The final chapter needed more padding
    [*]The process of getting every weapon and shield upgraded is a bit too time consuming. The thiefs glove and the corresponding skill that increases unique drops come way too late into the game.
    [*]There's a part halfway into the game where a character can die if you don't choose the right option and you lose access to an entire boss. I replayed about 4 hours of game just to go back and undo that decision.
    [*]The aforementioned inverse difficulty curve makes the game hard to stay satisfying at the end when you're bulldozing fights with no effort
    [*]The Growth screen is a bit awkward to navigate
[/list]

That's about all I've got. This is the very first game I've gifted to anybody else on the merits of the game itself. The developer should be proud of their accomplishments. Highly recommended to anybody who wants to play a pretty great ARPG.

[h1]Misleading journalism and actual play:[/h1]
What certain news outlets touted as the "lovechild of Final Fantasy and Castlevania" is a really fun game, though I would [b]NOT[/b] call it either of those things. It'd be a disservice to what this game is.

This game is its own thing. Sure, it shares some similar mechanics (weapon variety, "spells", license board-like power ups) but the meat of the game is in the fluid combat, how you go from melee to "magic" and back, the importance of using the right elements and the right abilities for each combat, and how each "build" is viable. It's a fun experience and a treat to both the eyes and the hands.

The downside is there's not much [b]real[/b] variety in the style of gameplay, if you want to blast enemies with magic, you have to use your weapons to charge up. If you don't care about magic and want to go full caveman, you're still gonna have a hard time passing up those i-frames and high-defense moments the spellcasting gives you. However, that's kind of a minor downside if you ask me.

The GREAT thing is how much you can customize. Seriously, you prefer to have a skill that lets you shield bash more often AND one that lets you put your shield up more quickly over having double jump? Sure, you can do it. You want to get skills to suck up money but don't have enough currency for activating the skill? There's ways around it. And don't get me started on the puzzles. They're great. Cleverly hidden, you're gonna probably feel like Sherlock or Poirot when you find the solutions. From what little I've played, NOTHING is there by accident, and that's amazing.

Now, the real downer is the translation: this game has got a terrible translation. I'm sorry, there's just no way around it, you're gonna be scratching your head half the time figuring out the mechanics of a skill or how to solve a puzzle solely on the fact that the translation is dead-wrong. Still, Google is a thing, most of the things have been asked already.

Hopefully I haven't scared you out of getting this gem.
Oh, did I mention it's criminally cheap? A true labor of love, this game.

130479992.review:
On the whole I like this game, but it has enough problems that I want to leave a negative review for the people like me who read those to get an idea of a game's flaws, especially given the current overwhelmingly positive rating. The demo should give a good idea on whether the basic gameplay will be fun for you, this review will mostly cover what isn't in the demo.

Let's get some positives out of the way first: The story is pretty good, it may seem a bit boring/generic at first but as it goes on it gains a lot of depth and intrigue to it. In particular the game does a very good job at making you dread things that you know are coming both in the short and long term. The basic combat system is pretty fun, with some of your progression systems expanding on it and giving you options in interesting ways, some of which can completely change your play style. Spells are fun and extremely useful since they're powerful and give you i-frames on cast. The variety of upgrade systems is interesting; LIBRA is particularly creative and well-done. Some of the progression systems can make things a bit grindy, but the game [i]usually[/i] does a good job with making the grinding fun (more on that later). The translation is a bit iffy at times, and sometimes this results in misleading information, but usually it comes across as charmingly earnest and there's a patch coming that's supposed to improve it.

The biggest issue I have is that the combat gradually becomes more and more of a headache as time goes on due to a few really questionable design decisions regarding your defensive options. Attacks with status effects still apply the status effect even if you i-frame through them, unless you block them, which requires having a shield equipped and that shield not breaking (if your shield breaks, it stays broken for a good 10-15 seconds, which might as well be 10-15 years). You do unlock an ability that makes you immune to status effects while spell i-frames are active, but it costs quite a few KARON points to equip while the ability to cancel most actions into a block only costs a single point. Eventually you'll be able to stack enough status resistance that this doesn't matter so much, but that won't happen until the endgame/postgame.

Even in the absence of status effects, 2 of your main i-frame sources (spells, backstep) have cooldowns while the third requires a successful block in order to trigger. However, the weapon mastery mechanic requires the occasional use of 2-handed weapons, and you really want to be leveling new weapons whenever you have them. 2-handed weapons do have a range advantage but it's not quite enough to negate the threat of melee attacks from most enemies even with the attack speed and stagger upgrades, and does nothing at all about ranged attacks unless you can use the environment to block them (which doesn't work with all ranged attacks, just most of them) or can get off a spell to block them (which requires having enough ST, which you can only get from getting enough hits in melee). Like with status effects, you eventually unlock an ability that lets you use a shield alongside a 2-handed weapon but it costs the maximum possible KARON points and the equipment that teaches it is from the final chapter.

If there are more than 2 or 3 enemies on screen (which happens frequently later on) you can forget about being able to see whether any of them are attacking under all the particle effects of your own attacks, which is an unfortunate choice in a game where blocking is so important and gets stronger when perfectly timed. This also affects a few bosses, in particular the postgame final boss.

The level design takes a huge dip in quality at chapter 6. The first half of the chapter is a constant blizzard that reduces your visibility while pushing you back and making all your movement related abilities worthless, with the only remedy for the pushing also making your attacks as slow as molasses. The other half is platforming over bottomless pits while dealing with enemies that either fully heal every other enemy on the map every 3 seconds, spam ranged attacks, or continuously block and have attack hitboxes twice as big as their attack animation, interspersed with puzzles that are so obtuse they wouldn't have been out of place in a 90s adventure game.

The start of chapter 7 is only a little better due to the sheer number of screens of boring flat terrain filled with enemies with annoying attack patterns. The second half of chapter 7 is, if anything, worse than chapter 6, thanks to how you lose access to your spells and KARON upgrades due to plot reasons. Thankfully the rest  of the game and the postgame make up for the chapter 6-7 dip in quality, with the partial exception of the postgame final boss who has the readability issues described above as well as an attack that can bug out and become almost impossible to dodge.

The "GROW" upgrade grid has some usability issues. You're unable to move off the rails of the path but the path is frequently convoluted - the chapter 6 part is an actual maze. Pressing Start teleports you to the beginning but this is actively useless since it's at the bottom left corner of the grid. Being able to move the cursor independently of the paths or at least teleport to different sections would be massively helpful. There's also a consistent problem with running out of one of the upgrade point colors because there are no enemies in your current chapter that drop them, leaving you the choices of either spending 3x as much, repeatedly crafting the same 1 or 2 food items, or skipping out on a bunch of stat points and magic until the next chapter, none of which feel very good.

Some negative reviews have complained about the treatment of women. As someone with a moderate tolerance for ecchi, I felt some of the complaints were exaggerated but others really weren't.

Some of it is dramatically appropriate, like a villain capturing your female party members and mentioning they'll be useful for his soldiers' morale. Some of it is genuinely funny, like the time the protag's lady friend sends him on a quest for panties so she can make him crossdress and help her replace the lesbians in the ritual sacrifice, only to find out she screwed up when ordering the commission so she has to give you [i]her[/i] clothes while [i]she[/i] wears the Leia bikini. Some of it is old hat anime tropes, like walking 500 miles to peek into the hot springs only to be immediately caught and destroyed for it.

But some of it is a big bare broad bearing bouncing balloon boobies being a boss battle for no bloody reason (I don't think it's possible to really describe this boss properly without getting flagged by Steam content auto-moderation), or a girl barging into your room and threatening to step on you and shove her panties in your mouth. The same girl is involved on both occasions, and NPCs sometimes comment on her looking a little young for you when she's following you. Moments like those are excessive enough that they sort of detract from the experience a bit. Fortunately there aren't very many of them, the game usually takes a serious tone, but that does make the questionable moments stand out that much more.

Edit: I have now finished the game + postgame, with all achievements except for 2 numerical grinds + beating the game on Difficult or higher (I played on Normal). Again, I do think this game is worth playing, as long as the caveats I've mentioned aren't dealbreakers to you.

130316465.review:
I am very happy to pick up Astlibra on a whim and played it until the very end. I wanted to play something nostalgic that have the feeling of SNES/PS1/PS2 Era games on the Steamdeck and Astlibra delivers!  This game is surprisingly a very good JRPG side scroller with a mixture of systems from YS/Castlevania/Final Fantasy and other SNES/PS1 Era games. The Steamdeck had no performance issues while handling the game making things enjoyable.

The story is solid and reminded me a bit of things from Anime with the plot twist and character development with time travel being prominent as the main theme of the game. The story along with the game play made the experience gratifying and now I want to play other classical games from past eras again.

The big selling point of this game to me is the fast pace combat system which you can fluidly control your character to dodge, block, or out maneuver attacks by positioning. Each weapon type like swords, two handed swords, claws, hammers, magic staves and spears each behavior differently making the game play unique while vanquishing demons.

The RPG mechanics for character building can be addicting by mixing and matching KARON skills earned from crafting/obtaining weapons and armor from chapters. Each weapon and armor have EXP you can grind out for new skills or magic crystals to invest in skills that are unlocked to customize the main character further. These skills can range from magic, melee, defense, movement, and looting. On top of that, you gain force from kills that can be used for GROW which is like the FFX sphere grid system to unlock stats, possessions (summons), and a few weapons/armors along the way.  Basically you can customize your character to suit your play style after putting in the work.

Another thing I loved about this game is the guard system by using a shield. It feels epic to block incoming attacks like a boss’s flame breath or claw strikes from hurting your main character from taking major damage. Things are balanced as well with the guard having a stamina gauge that runs out from blocking attacks successfully. While the bar refills, you must rely on dodging or avoiding attacks not to eat dirt or chug a healing item to keep fighting. The boss fights can be modernly challenging with the amount of attacks to dodge and mobs in later chapters making game play really engaging and epic. If things get too rough, a player can always reload a save to grind more skills/stats/weapons to retry the fight again better prepared.

Anyway, the only three cons I can think of for this game are:

1. The story has some janky translation in some places making the story rough to follow.

2. Some of the story is a bit misogynistic in some areas.

3. The puzzles can be tough in the main game for some of the chapters. There are resources online from the JP wiki that can help figure these out.

Lastly the soundtrack is really top tier and reminded me of stuff from JDK band from Falcom games and made the grinding really fun. Overall, I really enjoyed my time with Astlibra and highly recommend it, if you want to play an old-school JRPG game with roots of borrowing things from the golden age of SNES/PS1/PS2 era of gaming. Good Job KEIZO on a well-designed game!

129623877.review:
I did not expect what Astlibra Revision would turn out to be. When I first saw it and ignored it. When it was brought to my attention again and I’ve decided to play it. Even as I was playing it. It’s not some inventive never before seen mix of genres or anything, it’s just that it’s so constantly full of surprises. And huge. To a fault, really, but still, we’re talking about a game that looks like this lasting 60 hours and still finding ways to introduce some new stuff in the last hours of itself. But it’s also not without many issues.

Astlibra Revision is a hack and slash action RPG action adventure with a side scrolling view. It’s also, apparently, an updated release of a previously free game (hence the Revision in the title) and just thinking about how this could’ve been free makes my head spin. Not since La-Mulana or Cave Story a game like this was released for free, I’m pretty sure. Anyway, if the genre description doesn’t paint the picture for you, I’ll put it differently – imagine a modern Ys in side-scrolling 2D perspective and you’ll know what to expect from this game, at least in general. And, granted, Ys wasn’t the only series of Japanese action RPGs to have this kind of mix of mechanics, but Astlibra itself isn’t shy about reminding you of Ys in many various ways, so the comparison is only fair.

What this means is that you get a story-driven action adventure with lots and lots of monsters to combo to death, equipment and treasures to find, levels to grind, upgrades to be had and fun movement abilities to be experienced. The way the RPG mechanics are done in Astlibra is actually quite fun and borrowing from many other titles. For example, there are many skills that you get from “mastering” equipment by using it which have to be separately enabled or disabled using magic stones, which is very reminiscent of the Final Fantasy IX system. There’s a separate board of passive upgrades, which also contains skills and sometimes items to unlock, that is not entirely unlike the skill grids from FFX, XII or XIII. The amount of equipment is staggeringly huge and they all have separate classes that handle differently with a weight system in place to modify the speed of their usage. There’s a combo system that, just like in some Ys titles, modifies some of the parameters the longer you keep it going…

Jeez, there’s so much, really, that listing all of the ideas for item collecting, crafting (it’s more like cooking recipes here and not tedious), lore elements, permanent abilities and all of that stuff will turn this into a wiki page. But most important is that – all of these mechanics are actually very easy to understand and use and you can always ignore most of it and just focus on what you enjoy most. Or be like me and try to 100% the game which takes a long time… But a fun long time! And provides an additional bonus, just like in Ys, where you can (again, if you want) just grind to hell and back and have less trouble during harder encounters. Or, if you don’t want to, postpone all of the collecting and grinding til later and focus on smartly using all of the combat mechanics while being at a more reasonable level.

But yeah – you’ll have plenty of abilities to get stuff later, because this game is super packed with story chapters that simply don’t end. I don’t want to spoil much (or preferably anything), but I’ll say that there are very few permanently missable things in the game due to how it’s structured, so if you want to mostly follow the main story and ignore all of the optional stuff and do it later, you can do it. Because the story will just keep going… If I were to just write it down, chronologically, you’ll find it not particularly novel or that special. But I have to admit – the way it’s gradually revealed makes it extremely fun and interesting and even when I was expecting what would be revealed long before the game did that, those revelations still came at a good time. And you can always be sure that almost immediately after the game will throw a new unexpected thing at you and keep things interesting.

If only the writing didn’t suck butt… Ignoring the weird translation issues and odd phrasing at times, 30% of the writing is very solid and delivers the main story in a great way. Unfortunately, the rest of the game dialogues and narration lines are written as if by an extremely horny 13 year old boy still living in the late 80s. I mean, seriously, I’ve not seen such a dense pack of horribly outdated shonen tropes in a game since… actually ever. Everyone is constantly horny about the main character, every male is a pervert and men in drag is the most hilarious joke mankind ever devised, according to this game. It might sound like I’m exaggerating, but that’s really what the majority of the game dialogues is like, it’s obnoxious. And I fear that this might be the main reason a lot of people will bounce off the title, not wanting to deal with this crap. A lot of the last part of the game is, thankfully, better, but it never goes away and remains dumb til the very end.

A lot of people might just be like me and be able filter out all of that dumb crap just of the sake of how fun the game really is to play. To explore the locations, to run around, to engage in combat, to figure out the puzzles… Although, the last is another weaker point of the game – some puzzles are really cool in concept, but done very poorly. One of the early ones, for example, fully ignores the whole concept of crafting that you’ve been constantly using and requires instead to remember a joke cutscene that happened at least an hour ago (and if you were 100%-ing the chapter then several hours ago). Another feels easy to figure out the puzzle itself, but hard to realize the supposedly easy part of it because it’s counter-intuitive. And one is just easier to brute force than figure out. A shame, but I must admit that these are not bad puzzles and the solutions are fun and inventive, it’s just that the game doesn’t nudge the players the right way or at all to the solution when it should.

If you love playing Ys titles, you’ve probably ran off and bought this game already before even finishing reading my opinion. It’s a really fun and inventive take on that mix of genres and while a bit more primitive (and also more “oh my hand hurts from all the mashing”) in some aspects, it’s far more complex in others in ways that are interesting. If you’re just mildly curious about these kinds of Japanese action RPG titles or never tried them before – Astlibra Revision is a fun example of the genre that’s worth checking out. As long as you can stomach some poor writing, of course. Especially since the main story and the game world are really fun.

After fully beating this game, I can certainly say Astlibra is a masterpiece of the action JRPG genre. The gameplay is extremely fun, with a good mixture of button mashing while still retaining a need for situational awareness or tactics. The weapon experience system unlocking new abilities was always a treat, even if the weapons more or less played the same and having a shield was almost always better. I really enjoyed the designs despite that and working on a build that felt good for me to play. The summoning skills really add more depth to the gameplay as well, and I always found it fun to mess around with them and figure out which ones I liked or didn't like using for different encounters or areas. Just moving around in the game feels great, and everything is very responsive. That said, puzzles can sometimes be obtuse or confusing, and the EN translation isn't always consistent, but I can give it a pass.

The overall story was so much better than I expected, even if it does follow many JRPG tropes, which you may love or hate. It continued to surprise me up to the very end. Some things seemed like they were obvious only for the scene to be turned upside down onto its head as the story unfolded. My biggest complaints about the story were the silent and unnamed protagonist, even though multiple times he "talks" in a small wordless speech bubble and people say "this has your name on it" a few times, and the weirdly perverted moments that can be very typical of Japanese fiction. I was able to look past those moments for the rest of this beautiful gem, however, and I think if you can as well, you'll really like this game.

I would suggest this game to anyone who enjoys side-scrolling Castlevania games, DMC, Chrono Trigger, or the Final Fantasy series. It's not the type of game for everyone, but if you enjoy action RPGs and the JRPG genre I think this is absolutely worth your time and money. It hit almost all of the right buttons for me at the right time, and I basically played this game nonstop from start to finish. Absolutely incredible.

129354265.review:
Whew, well.  Like I always tell people. I rarely write reviews, and when I do its either for a game that deserves it meaning mostly its positive, or a short one which I will remove later being negative, like I did for RCG2 due to its release state.  Considering I been playing video games longer than most steam users have been alive, I pretty much seen it all.  Well thats enough intro  lets get down to it. 

Astlibra, a hidden gem of a game, coming out of nowhere.  Quite honestly in my opinion, could be a Indie nominee for the VGAs *I feel sorry for the VGA host, he almost, almost got to have one go without incident, just right there at the end, poor guy* And I say this due to how well created the game is, harking back to the old era of video games.  I see alot of primary influences in it, particularly the old Y's games, and a little bit of Drakken 2 Dragon View.  

What influences you may ask?  Oh I can name quite a few, even seen references to them.  Final Fantasy, Dragon Quest, Zelda, Chrono Trigger, heck even Metroid for a particular area.  The developers  who seemingly spent 15+ years creating this have obviously been playing video games for a long time, and are all what the Japanese term calls them "Your everyday Salaryman"  thus why it took them so long to create this.

The basic plot of a very, very long story, which, heavily influenced by both Chrono Trigger, and a very, specific game for a twist over midway thru,  is that you are a Silent Protagonist orphan who as a boy was attacked by Demons invading your village and tried to run away with your childhood sweetheart.  You both got surrounded, and then you lost consciousness as you got attacked by a giant powerful demon, only to wake up in a cabin in the middle of absolute nowhere with a talking Raven.  

You realize you are far, far from human civilization, so far that their are not even any demons around since they tend to stay near human settlements only for some reason.  You and the raven who seems to act as your surrogate father, tries to live life in this cabin, but your urge and desire to go back to your village and find the girl you have feelings for is too much, and you keep attempting to leave, only to realize the forest surrounding your cabin goes on seemingly forever. 

The raven then relents and decides to go with you and guide you.  The two spends eight, entire years, walking thru the frontier with no demons or humans in sight until finally you do come across civilization at last, and you are now a fully grown man.  Thus the adventure truly begins. 

The game uses some very beautiful background images, similar to how the SNES days have done it, with excellent character and monster animations with some enemies looking like they been hand drawn.  Its a action RPG combat system with near infinite stat growth, you can constantly keep getting stronger but to a certain extent.  You can gain levels, get these monster essences called Force, to boost your stats in a sort of stat board placement system similar to what FF 10 uses.  However to keep you from getting too overpowered, their is a maximum you can go on this Placement System which is defined by locks you cannot open until you reach the next chapter.  

You also have a skill system that uses Magic Crystals that you collect via various means.  You gain these skills by mastering the massive assortments of weapons, shields and armor.  Most of these will have a skill attached that once mastered, you can either use the skill for free long as you use that piece of equipment, or assign Magic Crystals to that skill to have it on permanently for as long as you have crystals assigned.  This allows you to customize your character to your play style.  

All this allows you to do basically three different types of builds I primarily see.  Want to be fast and defensive? Use a one hand weapon with shield,  with a shield you can block most attacks so long as they dont break your block gauge.   Spec to skills and stats that favors this.  Want to use a two handed weapon or thrusting weapon?  Spec for agility, use skills that boosts the range or speed of these weapons.  Want to use a magic staff and throw out fireballs and lightning like a wizard?  Spec for Magic over ATK and select skills that compliments Staff usage.  

You also have a summon system called Possession, which uses button inputs to dictate what you summon.  You earn these summons via the Stat board and they are categorized in six different elements. Fire, Water, Earth, Wind, Dark and Light.  You can set these summons however your play style or need is and they use a gauge called ST or Stamina which you regain simply from attacking.  Standard play loop is, attack until bar fills up, then use possession, then repeat.   Possessions are a way to cause massive damage all over, or to get yourself out of a bad situation.  I personally like using possession skills where you become the Summon for a fixed period of time allowing me to consume healing items in safety if needed.  

Due to near infinite stat growth, and of two, new mechanics that comes up post game, I wont spoil those, but I do wonder why the developer did not put those at the start.  I highly recommend to play the game on either Hell or Impossible difficulty, since the game seems balanced around those two difficulties.  You can change difficulties at will at any point until chapter 2.  Once you go past chapter 2, you can only go down in difficulty and cannot go up again.  Which is a weird design decision, I played the game on Hell and often wished I could put it up to Impossible since I am a completionist and I often will find ways to circumvent or cheese anything difficult.  I still had quite a challenge on Hell mode, but most bosses just seemed too easy due to the amount of grind I would put in and simply due to collecting all the weapons and armor to gain more skills or Magic Crystals.  

In short, if you want to be lightly challenged, play it on Hell, otherwise, I recommend Impossible if you want to at least 90 percent the game.  Many enemies and bosses can become bullet hells where dodging or blocking is needed depending on your playstyle.  Difficulty will determine how much you need to grind or simply be patient and dodge and block as much as possible. Just keep in mind the game has Near, infinite, stat growth.  You CAN with enough grinding, be so overpowered that even the true final boss, or the optional final arena boss, will be as weak as kittens to you, even on impossible, but that would take a tremendous amount of grind, and you would have gone and collected and done everything long before then either way, unless you get unlucky collecting....Hearts, at the near end. Wont spoil that. 

Now, the soundtrack.  Honestly again, I see influences from past games on this, particularly Y's.  Now most JRPG fans would have played a Y's title or two, and would know the awesome high energy soundtracks that tends to come from that franchise.  They did pretty well with this in Astlibra,  using the same high energy seen in Y's.  The first area, Volcano area, and Demon Castle being very notable.  Sounds fantastic and makes you pumped to play which is what I believe the developers were intending.  

Overall and I will say this, I have over 200+ games in my backlog.  Many on steam, many physical.  I have in my immediate concern to play and finish right now, Harvestella, Dragon Quest Treasures, Star Ocean Divine Force, Made in Abyss Binary star, Strangers of Paradise Final Fantasy Origins, and Sword and Fairy 7.  FF and DQ being in my top 5 franchises to complete start to finish. Yet, I chose to play this over them. 

Give it a shot. It well deserves your attention.

A charming and well-designed action adventure game similar to the Ys games on the SNES or Zelda 2. The gameplay is action-based combat with RPG elements in a sidescrolling format. The gameplay is tight and reactive, it's very easy to fumble your movement options if you get sloppy, but the default difficulty is forgiving enough to generally let you recover from mistakes. DO NOT ignore the Grow board, it is a bigger source of stats than actually levelling up and your actual main stat progression method. There are a couple puzzles that are a little frustrating in the way the game signposts the answers, but there are answers to them here and there if you want to look for them and can't get the answers on your own. 

The translation is a little stiff in the beginning, but don't let it put you off. The plot develops steadily and goes from a charming 80s style 7 to 11. I found the plot compelling and interesting, and they eventually wrap up all the core questions of the game. The game apparently had been in development a long, long, time, and the breadth of content is actually quite staggering once you've broken past the surface layers. 

The game is absolutely worth your time and money. If you like this kind of thing, get it!

This game is a masterpiece. I've spent over a 100 hours playing this.... so this should be a good indicator of how much I like this. The combat is great and I love how every weapon gets to be useful. Some may not fit your play style, but there are plenty to choose from. Daggers, clubs, swords, shields, great swords, spears, mage staffs, bows, crossbows, etc. Some weapons have different element types, some are faster, so the weapon with the highest attack power is not always the best.

There are lots of different skills to find which basically work as passives, about 10-12 different special moves, and a bunch of magic spells. Late game you unlock additional gems that can completely modify the original skills and magic spells. 

The game has a system which allows you to combine items into new items. The ingredients are mostly drops from monsters, which makes for a far better system than endlessly grinding for more money to get better equipment. 

The boss fights are large and enjoyable. Killing one of the major bosses actually feels meaningful here and serves to move the story along. If you want to find every item in the game, some back tracking will be needed but you can do so at any point in the game. Nothing that you can miss and lose out on permanently. 

A few minor things aren't translated too well, but its pretty much limited to the skill descriptions and it looks like the developers are patching it. You shouldn't let that stop you from enjoying an otherwise great game. 

I consider it to be a bargain at the $25 asking price, especially considering the amount of enjoyment I got from it.

Summary:  I recommend this game, but give the demo a try.  Not only does it have the "demo" mode which lets you try out abilities and feel around the combat AND acts as a tutorial of sorts, but you also get to play the first bit of the game separate from the demo.  Note:  The actual game starts off quite a bit slow, so don't write it off after only an hour or 2.  you've been warned.

I didn't think I would like this game from first impressions.  But seeing as how a demo was offered and others I talked to quite liked it, i tried it.  I like it enough to purchase it.  Even then, i thought "This game will turn out to be mediocre and i'll probably putter out and stop playing a few hours in after i got some fun out of it..."

Now here i am, 80 hours later (more like 76 hours of effective playtime excluding times i left the game running), %100 completion, beaten the game on the second hardest difficulty.  This game was just what I needed at this time.  There were times I cursed the game for some jank here and there, but overall, it is a solidly put together game, despite appearances.  The core gameplay feels good with a story constantly pushing you forward (unlike some other RPGs which put you on a hamster-wheel for far too long).
Expect to grind a bit though due to the nature of this RPG, the general murdering of enemies doesn't change too drasticly, but the game keeps things fresh in a variety of ways throughout the game. I have little experience in the Metriodvania category, the 2.5D sidescroller action rpg niche thing. The only other game that I've play similar is Symphony of the Night, which I played until the disc cracked. 

And even still, I played this game for days straight, got 100%, and am already waiting on the sequel. It brought me back to the younger days, on summer break, pushing Alucard to beat "luck-mode" with my younger brother on the sofa beside.

To start, the game is as hard or as easy as you want it to be, with 6 (I think) different difficulties. I played through on "hard" - once I got to about 75% completion though I wish I had selected one difficulty higher. 

The story was solid. It did get somewhat convoluted, but that happens with JRPGS, some of the translations could be better, but the majority of the dialogue was good. 

The combat is fast paced and fun. The skills and magic system are easy to use and critical in your success. Master weapons to learn new skills, unlock new magic through growth. There is a great selection of weapon types and styles, and in the back third or so of the game you can make even your starter gear as strong as the end game stuff. 

What I miss in the newer RPGs I play is farming - THE GRIND. Astlibra doesn't require you to dump HOURS into powering up your character, but if there's an empty bar that needs to be filled.... I'm gonna fill it. A huge plus for me was the multi-layered leveling system: You earn experience, you earn a spendable growth currency, and even weapon exp. In the back half of the game you can also find supplements to your gear that further enhance your stats and skills. 

I will eventually replay this. I will need to be in the mood to invest the time though, like SoTN it is an investment to clear completely.

I thoroughly enjoyed the time I spent on Astlibra Revision. I would recommend this game to any who are a fan of the genre, and even to those that haven't dip their toes in the water since Konami was king. 

These are the games the AAA studios should be pushing.

After a hundred hours of playing, I have finally finished this game, beaten the final boss, and borne witness to a beautiful ending. I am actually baffled that an indie RPG of this depth and quality exists; no matter how much I played, it always had something else up its sleeve to surprise me with. This is nothing short of a passion project with emphasis on the passion; I am actually moved to tears by having played something that is like... this. I haven't felt this way since [u]Undertale[/u]. I feel invigorated and purposeful for playing this game. I am actually angry at having played other indie games that aren't this deep, this full of content, this [i]passionate[/i].

I do have a couple of issues, though. I'm going to forgive the choppy translation and the hideous mishmash of textures and graphics; this is a passion project by someone in their basement, after all, and I expect it would be tremendously rough.

What I do take issue with is our hero having no name and no voice. The silent protagonist is a trend that I really wish would die in video games already as technology's evolved past the need to keep text boxes sparse in order to preserve disk space. Same goes for not having a name. It just feels weird and strange for everyone to call you "dear hero" or "this guy", and it's [b]especially[/b] weird when it is outright stated that your name is written somewhere in game but no one ever refers to you by it.

A character having no name and no voice is meant to allow the player to project onto them but that simply doesn't work here: our hero is indeed a character with driving motivations that characterise him, the search for Anulis. We should be drawn deeply into our hero's passionate and lifelong search for his beloved childhood friend but the lack of actual characterisation on display feels like a wall of jelly that I can't get through. What's more, the hero does talk to other people a lot and express himself but, without words, all you get are people constantly repeating everything you say like Solid Snake. "What's that, dear hero? You want to buck common sense and leap into danger to save them?"

A lot of scenes in the story are diminished by the hero's inability to speak but none more so than one specific moment near the very end. The knees of that scene absolutely buckle as it tries to convey what [i]should[/i] be a moment of such heartwarming sincerity and fulfillment but only has one half of it.

I stress that our hero is very much a character and so the typical strengths of a silent protagonist, however meager, do not apply here. If the protagonist spoke, the game would be so much better for it.

But this most certainly does not impede the quality of [u]ASTLIBRA[/u]. Play it. Play it play it play it play it play it. Play the demo. Be made curious by the demo so that you buy and play the whole thing. If you're a fan of [u]Ys[/u], this game will exceed every expectation you have and more. If you're a fan of any RPG ever, you need to play this because it nails the feeling that every RPG hopes to scratch. Just [i]give it a go[/i].

The good:
-Really enjoyable, satisfying hack and slash combat with endless customization. Each weapon, shield, and piece of armor has it's own unique skill that you can learn eventually, allowing you to mix and match different skill sets to fit your playstyle.
-Great boss battles (barring a couple, screw that volcano boss).
-The actual designs of the bosses and some of the monsters are really cool.
-An interesting story about time travel and it's consequences, not just in the story but also in the characters around you.
-A BANGING soundtrack.
-Plenty of puzzles that don't have logical, but not immediately obvious solutions.
-Clever uses of in-game mechanics used in the world. One example I just went through on my playthrough is that in order to pass a blizzard that is constantly pushing you backwards, you have to use the Weight mechanic by putting on your heaviest equipment so that it can't push you back anymore.

A solid game with two minor annoyances -- inconsistent mob placement and sporadically unintuitive puzzle design. 

Starting with mob placement, some areas are fine, other areas the dev just decided to stack about 30 enemies right on top of each other, which in turn just becomes annoying instead of fun or challenging. I'd rather fight 3 or 4 things that test my reflexes and keeps me on the edge of my seat rather than just slam head first into a giant swarm where it's literally impossible to read queues or telegraph enemy attacks. Honestly, enemy placement like that only promotes two types of game play -- ranged magic, or turtle shield tanking everything. That is, unless you want to use a lot of healing items. 

Moving onto the puzzle design, like mob placement, it seems there is no rhyme or reason as to when a puzzle makes logical sense. Some of them are so easy you can do them blindfolded, while others are so ridiculously cryptic I looked up the solution so I didn't waste my time. What's that? You want an example? Well, without giving any spoilers, there's a puzzle later in the game where you have to use a combination of skills to kind of "double jump and fly" to reach something you need to proceed. No, not double jump as in go higher (because that would make sense), you literally have to drop off a ledge and almost kill yourself by falling into an instant death bottomless pit, "glide" your head against the underside of said ledge, toss in a few double jumps, pray to Jesus, and suddenly you're there. The game gives zero indication where said item is located, either. To top it off, one of the skills you need to pull off this maneuver is hidden almost as well, and I never would have found it if not for a total accident of trying to double jump to save myself from dying after getting knocked off a ledge. Finally, to make matters worse, once you reach the item, you have to go through a hidden pathway in a wall via a ton of trial and error jumping (because you can't see yourself in the wall) to bypass a blockade. Literally the only way you locate this item is 1.) HOURS of exhausting all possibilities, or 2.) Look it up. This is something that should be hiding some powerful piece of optional gear, not a mandatory item you need to proceed through a door. Terrible design on that one.

Anyway, with my gripes out of the way, the game really does have quite a lot going for it. Trying to balance the scale to get the most out of buffs is oddly addicting, and I have spent a ton of hours just brainstorming different potential combinations. Throughout the game you get more and more slots for your scales, and it's just a lot of fun to try to be as well-rounded as possible without accidentally doubling a buff and not getting credit for one of them. A really cool system in my opinion.

I just finished the post game with an in-game time of 70 hours, and I plan to go back and get the rest of the achievements. I never expected to fall in love with this game, but it was captivating and never lost my interest. I'm a little sad that the adventure is over, but it's an experience I'll remember for a long time.

+ The gameplay is amazing. The combat starts off simple, but as you go through the game it gets way more interesting. The combat has a nice flow to it because you can cancel attacks into nearly anything, including jumps. Magic is performed buy holding the special button and doing a command, while entering the command the screen pauses (this can be disabled, and is always disabled above hard mode), so you can observe your surroundings and pick the right spell. Magic also has invincibility upon activation, but you can't spam magic to stay invincible forever because Stamina (ST) is needed to use magic. You build ST by attacking and if you don't hit an enemy with your weapon for too long, your ST begins to drain, additionally, after a spell is cast there's a cooldown before your attacks can build ST again. In addition to magic, you also have combat items that can be handy for enemy encounters or solving puzzles.

+ There are many customization systems that add to the combat; a skill tree you spend force on to gain stats and learn magic, attribute points you earn from level ups that can be reallocated, abilities you can equip using magic crystals, and the Libra system that allows you to use items to get bonuses. Every weapon, armor and shield gains experience as you use them and when mastered you either learn an ability or get a magic crystal. Mastered equipment also lets you equip the ability they teach for free, and if they don't teach an ability their stats are enhanced. All of these systems work together to create a fluid and fun combat system. The game's combat is constantly evolving thanks to the systems and it always feels fresh.  Once you beat the main story, the game introduces even more systems but i'll leave those as a surprise. Lastly, the game has a lot of great boss fights, so the complex systems aren't wasted. I played on Hard, and felt the game had a nice challenge.

+ The story is very entertaining. The Hero is a semi-silent protagonist; there's no text when he speaks, instead he speaks in the story through ineligible speech bubbles and there's always a lot of context to figure out what he's saying, but you have to use your imagination to see how he communicates. I was a nice change of pace from the standard silent protagonist in RPGs since the Hero still reacts to events around him. There are many twist and revelations that are foreshadowed and push the story in an interesting direction while giving it some complexity. The game has a lot of dialog, but I felt it (usually) paced the cutscenes and gameplay well. I'd go into a deeper dive, but I don't wanna get into spoilers.

+ The music is fantastic. There's over 100 songs and many of them are memorable; from catchy songs on the map to heart pumping boss themes, there's a wide ranges of music that's used effectively.

+ There's tons of content. With Six secret bosses, an arena, a 10-20 hour post game and more, you'll be spending dozens of hours trying to do everything.

+ I  never encountered crashes, so the game was very stable. The game also works great on Steam Deck.

* The visuals are a mixed bag. The art is great, but the enemy animations could use some work.

- The translation is rough. It's good enough to read and understand what's going on but there's grammatical errors, typos some phrases that read awkwardly, etc. They've been improving the translation with patches, so this con could go away.

- The Lich King in Chapter 5 is the worst boss in the game, he shouldn't be allowed to summon the Wyvern (a mini boss you fought earlier in the chapter).

- Fighting [spoiler]Geas Roots[/spoiler] 7 times in the post game was too much. I understand why it happened, but I wish each fight varied more.

Honestly, every issue I had with the game is minor and they didn't affect my enjoyment.

Astlibra Revision is a hidden gem and I don't say that lightly; one of the best games I've played all year and I highly recommend it. I'll be there for KEIZO's next game day 1

The music is a fitting thematic assortment of electronic pop/synth/rock with tracks unique to each main location, motifs for certain characters and types of scenes (sad/ironic/moving). Quite a few tracks stand out as what might be called "bangers" and none of the background tracks are jarring or take you out of the moment.

Sound design is surprisingly good. Every attack, movement, and skill has great audio feedback and adds a lot of weight to the action -- especially when hitting multiple enemies and the stacking SFX makes a satisfying CHA-CHA-CHUNK. 

There are many games that come out at full price ($50-60 or regional equivalent) that release without feeling feature-complete, so it feels like you should wait until a sale to buy. $25 USD (the current price as of this review) feels like it's under-costed for what this game truly is, so there's no need to wait. I was hesitant at first, especially at the opening video and the seemingly low end graphics of the game. However I downloaded the demo and played it to the end and had to immediately buy it. The gameplay more than makes up for the mediocre but passable graphics, as well as a killer soundtrack that you can play from the title screen with each track you 'unlock' as you play the game.

PROS:
- JRPG Story base and in depth character development (though it may take a few chapters for this to set in)
- Metroidvania Goodness, hack and slash -esque combat with a diverse way to customize your character to handle any challenge the game puts forth.
- Summons! Six different elements you can assign a summon to, and each category has a slew of different summons you can unlock and customize a loadout with
- Massive and extensive skill web (Reminiscent of FF10 or Path of Exile, Salt & Sanctuary, etc.)
- Equipment learning system: Mastering Weapons/Shields/Armor will grant you perk points or perk skills allowing you to customize yourself with unique and powerful passive abilities, like double jump, treasure finding, and the like
- Item Crafting System: Large and extensive crafting recipe system to create items that will help in your progression through the game
- Item Stat Gains: A system allowing you to set certain items in special slots that give permanent bonuses while equipped and can save multiple different sets allowing for different loadouts, such as farming or debuff resistant builds
- Free Respec: At any time (at certain locations) you can alter your stats from your level ups, adjusting as necessary to the challenges presented in the game
- Combat system that is in depth and grows as you learn more skills throughout the game, such as perfect guarding, parrying, shield bashing, etc.
- Bosses, bosses FEEL like bosses, always an amazing boss battle music accompaniment and amazing artwork for the bosses you encounter, and use of mechanics to win later encounters. You can't just roll face across the keyboard to win depending on the difficulty you play at, but normal and above you can only get away with that for the first one or two 'intro' bosses.
- Replayability! You always have the option and opportunity to return to locations you've been before even if it doesn't feel like it, so if you've missed something you can always come back, as there are rewards for full completion.
- Length: The game is long, from start to finish and including the post game (yes there's actually a section the game itself refers to post game that is required to 'finish' the game) As of the time of writing I think I'm within the last two chapters and I've put 40 hours into it. So its well worth the money for a Metroidvania RPG

CONS:
- Story is very much in JRPG style, so with the pros that brings there are also cons, there are some cringe-y tropes that are associated with that that pop up here and there. If you can get past that, its not really that big of a con but some can take away from the seriousness presented in the story.
- Puzzles, story progression does require some puzzles to be solved to advance, and while NPC placement allows to offer hints to push you in the right direction some puzzles will make you question your existence, and there's not a huge online support for guides or reference to this game other than youtube playthroughs (at the time of writing this review)
- After a while the game encourages grinding like a typical JRPG would warrant, but in a metroidvania setting that's not difficult to do, but at the same time monotonous and sometimes tedious, not that grinding in any game is fun or fulfilling but it is a boring point of the game unless you mix things up and use it to try new builds and equipment loadouts or try to master equipment.
- Arena Missions: There is an arena that poses 5 challenges per chapter of the game and offers almost necessary rewards to progress through the game and most have timed challenges or 'don't get hit' requirements that make them difficult and sometimes grueling. I personally don't like arena type challenges in games unless they are truly optional or the reward is just a really good item that isn't entirely necessary. Not in this case. Thus it is listed as a con for me, but I know some people actually like challenges such as these.

Takeaway:

If you like having full control over stat and character progression this game gives you that control, and even manipulation over it, as well as passives and active skills alongside actual equipment loadouts. And there's so much progression you don't get to feel like you're capped out or you're done, as there is always more. The game is always kind and gives you a heads up when you'll be going away from the 'hub' and be locked into an area until its completed so that way you can prepare accordingly and even after transitioning there will be shops available for continuing access to supplies so you're not left high and dry. Even with the cons and complaints I have with the game the Pros greatly exceed them, and I would list this in my top 5 metroidvania games.

Entertaining combat and interesting progression... muddled by a cliche story and horribly cringe dialogue. I have to preface this saying the dialogue feels like it was written by a teenager going through puberty, it's agonizingly perverted and borders on being offensive to women. Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game. I will split this review into two categories: Combat and Story, I'll sprinkle in progression/exploration along the way. Don't worry I will not spoil anything related to the story, although frankly the story is so cliche you wouldn't really be missing out on anything.

Combat:

The main selling point of this is the combat system. The controls are surprisingly fluid, despite how the game looks in the trailer. How the combat works is you have a variety of different weapon types, these are all pretty basic and uninteresting. Where it gets interesting is the magic system. Magic doesn't use a standard MP pool, rather you get MP by attacking monsters and it degrades over time. What further enhances the system is when you use magic you are invincible temporarily. This makes combat have a nice flow where you attack to gain mana and then quickly use a magic ability to block enemy attacks while continuing the combo. It's very reminiscent of Bloodborne where it emphasizes attacking over defense. The combat isn't always consistent (magic can block damage, but not status effects like petrification or poison), but it's definitely the highlight of the game.

The world is not interconnected, rather it follows a hub-style system. Your main base of operations leads you to separate areas in the world instead of it being woven into one giant map. Think Demon Souls vs Sekiro. This isn't a negative point towards the game, but is something to note about how it's different from most modern metroidvanias that have interwoven maps like Hollow Knight. Progression is grindy, but pretty basic overall. Each area has a fixed number of special equipment of each type (two weapons, one shield, one armor, one accessory) that you can find via chests. This is separate from each area having its own shop with a large selection of new weapons, armors, and accessories. I must reiterate, there are a wide variety of different weapon types, but they all function the same and only change from a stat perspective. So a spear from chapter one functions the same as a spear from chapter 3 outside of it having upgraded stats and maybe some debuff/elemental damage tied to it. There are a few actual unique weapons in the game, but they're small in number. 

Story/Dialogue:

The main story is about time travel, however it doesn't flow very well. Each chapter ends with a b-roll and credit sequence. This tells me the developers may have released the game in parts rather than everything being a cohesive narrative, and it shows. It comes across as very jarring at times with how flip floppy everything is. Each chapter functions as its own separate story which also slowly progresses the main plot point. Every chapter is one cliche after another. The vast majority of characters function in their own chapter only and you will never see them again. I'm honestly surprised by how many reviews are praising the story. It's filled with plot holes and inconsistencies. The only saving grace is that there are choices with consequences, but even that has no value because the game has a bunch of flags telling you the choice you made could have consequences in the future.

Now comes the worst part... which is the dialogue. It's atrociously bad. It was written with the developers dicks rather than their brains and it shows. Female NPCs are constantly calling your character different shades of attractive. Male NPCs cat call female NPCs and companions constantly and are outright creepy about it (an old man talks about the breasts of a teenage girl????). One of the female companions will threaten to wake up the main character by "putting their sweaty feet on your face" while he is sleeping or "removing their used panties and stuffing it in the main characters mouth". Overall, the combat is interesting but is marred by the average story and terrible dialogue.
