I am thoroughly enjoying this game so far. It's a really interesting and slightly complex story but I've been interested the entire time, even enough to read additional in game lore books and the like. 

For a JRPG the grind doesn't feel all too bad, but I also haven't done any end game stuff yet, so I could be very wrong about this soon, so far though resources/money/experience and equipment mastery have been easy to gain and have consistently grown in proportion to the difficulty. 

This game is an action JRPG, and a unique one at that. While the animations look a bit choppy, the game play is quite smooth, and it encourages the use of all skills at your disposal, the controls are very polished in this regard as well, the game feels fun and intuitive to play. 

This game is either a collectathon enjoyer's worst nightmare or dream game. There is a ton of things to collect whether it be magic abilities, weapons and materials, equipment skills, filling out the "growth" map., etc. A ton to do, however it's made more rewarding due to the fact that you can easily plan out very efficient farming routes for both enemies and resources all while swapping in and out weapons/shields and armor to max out equipment skills or get an item for 'mastering' the particular weapon or armor all at once. 

Also by equipment skills I mean abilities like passive upgrades to attack speed, or elemental damage, or even item magnet abilities. You can use them for free if you have the weapon or armor equipped, or you also have a growing ability to use unequipped but mastered skills which grows over time. 

The actual combat itself, while it feels nice does get a bit mundane as eventually when you get good at it, it's quite easy at normal difficulty. There is a variety of things you can do combat wise, and it grows over time as you collect combat abilities. Though these you usually get from chests it seems. Blocking is valuable as well, it's great for projectiles and protects against status ailments. You also can utilize the invincibility frames you get when you use the magic in this game, and you use both ranged and melee abilities along with magic as sort of a catch all Gary Stu type. 

On top of this you also have a variety of items you can use to fit any situation, from all enemies in a room being heavily damaged, to throwing an arrow by hand which is surprisingly powerful early on. The game also utilizes a delayed item use system. So you use a healing item, a progress bar appears, and then the item is used. If you are struck/leave that zone etc it will cancel it. It hasn't been difficult to break away from fights to heal/shoot a bow at a distance as well. 

No autosave system, save often, and when you interact with a save point all enemies not in that zone are resurrected. If you leave your zone and come back those enemies do respawn as well.

There is a lot of depth to this game too. An arena with multiple and varied "cups" ranging from platforming  and combat challenges to speed challenges. You are able to backtrack after you've progressed to a certain point in the story, so don't overly stress on leaving things behind. Though the catch is you have to complete the chapter again. Makes the game ideal for speed runners I guess. You even get your own house and back yard. Unknown if any visual or functional customization is possible. 

There is a lot of freedom in character customization as well. You can allocate 5 points to attributes every level, but you can reallocate them as you see fit at specific points scattered throughout the game, and there is some strategy to this, even terrain dependent strategy. You're well served just bumping attack, defense, and health too, at least as far as I've gotten in the game.

There are many puzzles, and a lot of context clues as you watch cutscenes. This game is cutscene heavy, so for those of you who may remember that boss fight with Riku during the old PS2 KH1 days you can rejoice, for this game features a skip button.

It's a semi silent protagonist. I think it's deliberate, as the character will talk in game, but you can't see his words. There is always context that let's you know what he's talking about, but let's you sort of fill in the blanks of how he communicates it with your own imagination.

This game plays excellently on Steam Deck. There's some choppy audio, but I've not been bothered enough to try and fix it, so there may be a workaround for it I just haven't utilized. It's also really good with the battery life. Like you're hitting the top end of the "possible hours" of a single charge. Though that may be obvious as its not that graphics intensive. 

Overall I definitely recommend this game, there's a lot to do and it's very approachable but if you want to can turn the difficulty up to 11. I haven't tried that yet so I don't know how the challenge is balanced, I would say it's likely a damage sponge method given the health pools of some bosses. This is speculation though, and it could be user error with regards to my damage output, so your milage may vary. 

Lastly, it's pretty clear a lot of love and care went into this game, and I think the developer nailed something really cool, unique and fun to play here. There's even a demo if you really need to see for yourself. I believe that this game is definitely worth picking up.


*Edit: I am incorrect about having to complete whole chapters over if you go back to them.

Game finished edit: I can honestly say this is a must buy for me. Probably if not definitely my GOTY. I literally played non-stop until I finished it, and I didn't feel like any part of it was a chore except one specific thing at the absolute very last part of the game, but even then the methodology is interesting and fun for the most part. You're doing yourself a disservice if you like anything that you see on this page and don't pick it up in my honest opinion.

[b][i]AsuReDi posting for duty![/i][/b] I played Astlibra Revision on Twitch and posted on YouTube. Went through the main game and post game story. TLDR: Good game, alright story, lots of fun mechanics, really fun but challenging in a technical way on Difficult / Hell difficulty. Expanded thoughts below:

[hr][/hr]

[b]Gameplay[/b] - Plays similarly to some side-scrolling action platformers, thinking Castlevania series. Character has a bit finer motion control, several fun movement and attack abilities, etc. Magic feels varied and presents unique attack / defense opportunities, especially combined with Karon's skills that can totally change mechanics. There are tons of items to collect, lots of mix and match stats, and the different weapon classes feel unique. Bosses are fun, trash mobs have varied looks and basic attacks, and the levels are passable. I did have some frustration on some sections (the hopping enemies that attach to you and make you bleed... I love those @_@). Overall, very fun game.

[b]Visuals[/b] - Decent visuals. Reminiscent of flash gameplay, but it's a little more polished. Most big boss sprites look great. Enemies have decent enough palettes and silhouettes to be recognizable and fun. But yeah, the bug bosses and effects are where the game shines. My only minor complaint, especially in the postgame bosses, is there would be enough going on I would sometimes lose track of my nameless hero. Or the attack particles / sprites would get hidden by flashes and other effects. Not terrible, but playing on Hell with the Berserk skill active... left me ripping a few blue hairs out of my gorgeous locks.

[b]Music and Audio]/b] - The general audio (voice sound, effect sounds, etc) are good. Not great, but good. They are distinct enough you can tie sounds to specific effects, abilities, etc. They also have enough impact to make you feel like you're hitting, taking hits, etc. However, the game really shines with its soundtrack. I noticed a lot of [i]sakuzo[/i] pieces, which I loved. I also loved a lot of the future themes. Really amps up the gameplay. Nothing felt out of place in the game, and all the general / action pieces got my 'engine revving,' he he.

[b]Story[/b] - This is probably the weakest part of the game. I enjoyed it, but the post-game story definitely takes the wind out of the main narrative. Somewhat overstaying its welcome. The characters are all fun, if not a bit tropey (how many times do we have to discuss groping, pervy thoughts, and scandelous things ladies?). But it's all in a PG way that is overall fun. Time-travel stories all get weird anyway. And there's a bit of mixed moralization in some places. Overall, serviceable story, fun tropey characters.

[hr][/hr]

[b][u]Final Verdict[/u][/b] - Good game with great gameplay, decent visuals, decent technical combat, a really good soundtrack, and an okay story. Definitely something worth buying and playing if you are into side-scrolling action rpgs.

125253380.review:
Astlibra is something that hardly any other game is these days. It's a finished and incredibly polished. 

Astlibra can easily take its place among the JRPG behemoths of the 16 bit era, and it may well be one of the best -if not THE best- JRPG ever made. The fact that this was created by a single person is simply mind blowing.

Although you can still clearly feel the indie jankiness in the game, it has been polished to the degree where it just becomes its art style. At times you feel like you're playing a mid-2000s flash game that has been iterated on a million times until it was effectively a AAA release. It borrows stylistic elements from at least a dozen other successful IPs yet manages to outshine most of them in execution.

While I could go on endlessly about the things Astlibra does well, let me critique the few things that it didn't. 

- The music is sometimes a bit of off. While overall the soundtrack has been very good, it does have weak points.
- The translation work is occasionally lacking. It's not nearly as bad as it could be, but you can tell it's a game made primarily for a Japanese audience.
- There is a strong focus on grinding for power. This is perfectly fine and expected in the genre, but especially towards the level 40-50 areas you are no longer expected to grind where the story takes you. If you fail to figure that out, it can feel like you're running into a brick wall.
- The hardest challenges in the game effectively turn into bullet hell gameplay. That's also fine, but at times the visual clarity is severely lacking which can make the challenge feel artificially difficult.
- There are some random pop-ups of out of place sexually suggestive art that can at best be explained by "Japanese game". They are very few though.
- The optional content (i.e. arena challenges) are not very optional at all and yield de-facto required items.


To recapitulate: 10/10, amazing game, would recommend to anyone even remotely into JRPG.

125034671.review:
[TL;DR at the bottom] 

I found Astlibra by chance through a friends’ recommendation after the Next Fest and having never been that much into Side-Scrolling Action RPG’s, nor Metroidvania, the only thing that really stuck with me was the rather unique art direction. A 61-hour long obsession later, it’s ridiculous how Astlibra has become hands-down the best game I have played all year.

From a technical standpoint, Astlibra ran fine. I’ve experienced no crashes or other miscellaneous performance issues. However, there have been some minor issues that would appear every now and again, such as the game struggling to initiate dialogue when approaching an NPC from the wrong side, or spawning enemies and chests in odd positions. One achievement did fail to fire during gameplay but was awarded when I next booted the game so it really all just amounts to, at worst, minor annoyances.

The most blatant issue instead is the translation. I am no stranger to games that aren’t mainly developed in English, and Astlibra has been continuously improving, but currently still features a myriad of typing and punctuation errors – or at worst thorough mistranslations. As an example, and I fully expect this to be fixed fairly soon, is a skill that reads: “Resistance to all abnormalities +10, break damage increased 1.5 times" – whereas the actual effect causes you to take 1.5x damage instead. The overall game is coherent, but you're bound to stumble over some oddities in its script, regardless of whether it is item descriptions, skills, or story sequences.

Graphics and Soundtrack are a bit more mixed and I’ve even seen other reviews criticize it as looking ‘stock’ – personally, I found it captivating; Almost Madoka Magica-esque which leans quite well into some of the more ‘out-there’ chapters of the remarkably unique story. Now the issue for some may be less the artstyle, but rather how inconsistent it is sometimes applied – a criticism that does overlap with both the soundtrack and seeps into the writing every now and again; A scene may be macabre and nightmarish but is also always contrasted by character-designs and writing like Gau, that feels more akin to a regular Shounen Anime. In short: There is a lot of tonal whiplash that touches every aspect of the general atmosphere of the game. Nevertheless, the takeaway should still be that the presentation, music – and especially the writing is competent: The latter especially is captivating by virtue of the setting alone and presenting a take on an often awfully mishandled genre. 

Gameplay is an entirely different deal however. As it stands, Astlibra shines through a myriad of different character progression systems – you have regular stats, physical, magical, defensive, utility – which can all be enhanced on their own per level up. Naturally gear also carries stats, but where it becomes more interesting is by each piece of weaponry and armor also having an innate skill that can be earned by actively using it. Alternatively, maxing out a piece of equipment may also give you a greater limit in how many of these skills you can use simultaneously. Then a third way to progress is by the Force-Grid; Essentially an experience-like resource that can be spent on an ability-grid which is a bit comparable to Path of Exile, or Final Fantasy 10. The result is that grinding feels extremely rewarding – and not just rewarding, but also avoids repetition by incentivizing constantly switching your loadout. 

Another system that is thematically interesting and a way to progress your character aside from raw grind is the Libra – a set of scales that is upgraded throughout the story/exploration and that provides differing benefits on the basis of which items are being placed on them. Basically every item in your inventory that is not equipment is assigned a weight and innate stats (i.e. A bonus to attack power); An item placed on the scales provides its effect if it is countered as much as possible by another item with a differing effect. 

Some aspects of the core stats may be a little too ambiguous; Such as Adaptability not mentioning its effect on your resistances, or providing sufficient information on soft-caps and just how exactly the trillionth investment in Speed scales (heh). This may be a positive for some as it, too, encourages experimentation and mixing up your playstyle and at the end of the day is never really that big of an issue regardless, but may also be a symptom of the current translation status.

Combat is fluent, but struggles a little with a proper difficulty curve. Playing on Hard from start to finish, the game felt perfectly fine – if a little easy during the initial chapters, consistently ramping up to a jump in difficulty around Chapter 6, which is also right around the time I started going after the optional bosses. After a few more chapters and upon unlocking the additional progression systems during late-game, the difficulty not just plateaus, but completely inverts in the favor of the player. At this point, you’re likely to have spent around 40+ hours, but it is still a little disappointing that the game never managed to catch back up to the escalation in player power.

Something that could have alleviated this may have been the inclusion of multiple peripheral game modes. As it stands, between story progression and grinding, the player only ever has access to an arena mode of different gimmicky fights. Likewise, while it is possible to change your difficulty down; it is not possible to set it higher – something that I definitely would have appreciated to counteract some of the more dry sections towards the finale of the game.


[u]TL;DR[/u]
+ Expansive 40-60+ hour story that is extremely focused at the cost of not featuring a lot of peripheral content.
+ Well-developed and deep character progression that properly incentivizes experimenting with the combat system.
+ Shiro’s wake-up calls.

+/- Competent setting that tackles [spoiler]time-traveling[/spoiler] in a way that I have not seen in any other game, anime, book, or otherwise. However, the writing may suffer due to tonal whiplash and a more general lack of direction within the last chapter(s) of the game.
+/- Unique art-direction that leads to some of the most memorable enemy designs I’ve seen, but is also often contrasted by a similar tonal whiplash that I have described for the story. 

- Balance and Difficulty begins to crumble after the introduction of late-game progression systems and could be easily alleviated by allowing the player to tweak the difficulty freely rather than only to lower it.
- Currently rather lackluster translation – While generally coherent, there are very apparent errors that tend to stick out and may be immersion breaking. Likewise mistranslated skills could lead to genuine frustration.

Even reading this back to myself before posting, it’s very apparent that Astlibra is far from flawless – but that’s not really the point. The developer understands what makes the genre *fun* - regardless of any quirks the game may carry. It is *fun* to grab new weapons and to experiment. It is equally *fun* to progress from chapter to chapter and follow the small tidbits of character stories – some intentionally or unintentionally humorous, some serious - to anticipate the next big story beats and enjoy the twists and turns along the way. It all works in the end, even if the game is a little janky - that bit of jank makes it all somehow click together. It is confident from start to finish and oozes with charisma and soul that many newer games simply do not have.

124861435.review:
[h1] One of the best games I have ever played in 24 years of gaming. [/h1]

I grew up playing old-school adventure game / RPG's when they were new. Your Final Fantasys, Secret of Mana, Castlevania, Act raiser, Valkyrie Profile etc. There's been a drought of JRPG's lately, and I sorted Steam by the JRPG tag to see what was up. Most of the games were fine, but nothing really piqued my interest or my eye. Then I saw a game with a funny name, terrible graphics and "overwhelmingly positive" for the reviews. I scanned the page, watched the trailer and checked out some images. The old-school progression and side-scrolling combat looked fun, but even an older dude like myself was completely turned off by the graphics.

I am so glad that I gave it a chance despite my first impressions. This is one of the best games I have played in the past decade, perhaps even in my lifetime. I put this game up there with other genre-defining titles such as Final Fantasy VII/IX/X, Nier, Nier Automata, Legend of Dragoon and the likes of Squaresoft/Enix's blockbusters. If you are anything like myself and are interested in this game but turned off by the graphics, please give this game a chance. With this out of the way, I'll get into the review proper, taking the most time with the gameplay systems and tackling graphics last.

[b] GAMEPLAY [/b]: Gameplay is a 2D side scrolling action game like Castlevania is. The thing here is the game has MANY avenues for character progression, with some of the options being incredibly interesting and different from what the industry has done previously. These features heavily influence the aforementioned 2D side scrolling action combat. You have an equipment system where nearly every piece of equipment in the game has a skill which you need to earn enough EXP to unlock (Think Final Fantasy IX). These range from simple stat boosts to straight-up entirely new mechanics that you will weave into your gameplay loop.

You have a "scale" system, where you have to put in items you collect on your adventure (Potions, food items, materials, monster drops, etc) to gain bonus stats. Each item has a weight value attached to it, and your goal is to balance these sets of scales according to the benefits the item in question brings and the weight it has attached to it. This causes a lot of thought based on what stats you value and how to make them work in the confines of the weight attached to them.

And finally you have "possession" skills that rely on a meter you fill up with active combat attacks. These skills are varied, you can swap them out for other skills, and using them makes you invincible for a short period upon activation. These skills range from buffs, to attacks, to utility and more.

What makes this game such a masterpiece is how all of these systems work together to form such a fluid combat system that has an immense amount of depth and fluidity. You learn the basics in the first 5-10 hours of gameplay, and you're constantly having new tools available to the player as you progress but nothing makes anything else obsolete. They just give you more options and more tools to mix up the flow of combat by weaving these options together. Most of these tools have either cool downs/resource bar requirements to work and how you play the game will drastically change depending on how aggressive you want to be in encounters. You COULD run it, hit the boss a few times and run out and block, or you could mix up Possession skills for invincibility to block a huge boss attack, be aggressive, block a few attacks with your shield - but now your block gauge is gone and you have no meter for Posession skills, so you backslide for the iframes THROUGH a boss attack to get enough meter and shield gauge to continue the flow of combat.

I could honestly go on and on about simple things, such as how the hitstop slows combat down enough so that you can see the insane amount of action on the screen at once so you can make a decision that would not be afforded to you if you were playing passive and NOT slowing down the combat with the hitstop. It is so fluid and masterfully executed that I'm beyond impressed that a single guy managed to pull off what I consider to be one of the best combat systems I have ever played in a game. The combat is as intricate as you want it to be. The better you, as the player, will determine how aggressive and relentless you will be.

[b] STORY [/b] - The story is excellent. I wasn't expecting much, but I was honestly really impressed with what I got. It started out as a simple story with some intrigue, light-hearted themes with some melancholy thrown in. As you continue to play the game the world, its characters and its plot opens up and becomes more and more intriguing with the stakes being raised through your action. I can't go too in depth without spoiling the game, but I will say that this game can blend future-dystopian themes with gods, folklore, demons and mechs. What's amazing here is how Mr Keizo has let these themes be disjointing when they need to be to suit the story, and seamless and fluid when that is important to the story. Nothing touched on in this story is pretentious, and the story itself is pretty simple as far as a story involving time travel can go. But it's humbling, it's comforting and while it doesn't reach the insane heights' something like NIER does, it's a competent and compelling story in its own right. You end up caring for the characters, the world and the story. The only issue is some rough translation work that can make some of the script come across as a little "stiff" at times, but it's not too intrusive to take away from the experience.

[b] MUSIC [/b] - The music is fantastic. There's your standard fantasy violin tracks, piano pieces and it all is really competent and makes the world feel alive. When the story needs it, it even has modern tracks like some electronic with vocals that honestly sounds wonderful. I felt like each piece fit the location really well, with the exception to a couple tracks that honestly really did not fit their encounters. JRock when fighting a fiery demon god? I can dig it but it just didn't really fit and kind of took me out of that fight.

[b] GRAPHICS [/b] - And here's what I saved for last, and with good reason. Out of all the cons I have for the game (Some area design from a gameplay standpoint, enemy placement, enemy design from a gameplay standpoint) graphics are objectively pretty poor. The developer, Mr Kezio, was virtually a one-man team and did what he could with what he had. The terrain is especially jarring, but when you take into account the fact it was one man working on this I feel like it's forgivable. I would argue that perhaps due to the limitations on the graphics that the other systems were allowed to be so fleshed-out and shine like they do. The graphics ended up appealing to me after a while, perhaps Stockholm syndrome. The quality improved a lot as the game went on, which I have to assume was due to the game being a 14-year passion project by a lone guy. If anybody is going to be turned off from the game, I have to imagine this is where it will be. I hope you will overlook them, as the game itself is a complete masterpiece, but I understand if you cannot.

[b] CONCLUSION[/b] - This is perhaps one of the best, most fluid and cohesive games I have ever played in my life. The gameplay is unbelievably well executed and imagined, and the story and the supporting systems add a level of depth and versatility that is refreshing and honestly startling given how this was made by one guy. This game is a masterpiece and deserves your attention. I could go on, but character limits and all.

Do not be put off by some of the animations and visuals, this game is a top tier hidden gem.  A stunningly massive 2D action RPG spanning upwards of 70 hours.  This is probably in my top 3 new releases I've played this year (Elden Ring and Crystal Project being the other 2). There are multiple difficulty options as well to make the game feel the way you want it to,

Easily the best 2D RPG I've played in years.

Top tier value for money, a full run took about 57 hours on hard (I did everything there was to do), only to unlock what seems to be a "New game+" that unlocked more character progression methods and more story. Amazing stuff.

In short, it is a side scroller with lots of different character progression, some focus on story and a lot of combat. The game is tagged as a metroidvania, but I'd consider that to be false. Each chapter is straight forward, yes you unlock stuff like double jump and dash, but it's not used to access previous areas in order to progress. It's mostly used to grab items and QoL.

The combat and especially the keybinds on controller may take a bit of getting used to. Blocking by pressing "down" and dodge backward bound to "right trigger" is a bit strange to begin with, but you get used to it.

[list]
    [*] This is a grinder. On hard you *must* grind a fair bit. but with this combat and so much stuff to unlock i actually just loved this
    [*] Some of the puzzles use force you to think outside the box, they are not that complicated at all, but the game expects you to know the items you have in your inventory. An example of this is that you will be using a item form chapter one in a late are puzzle
    [*] The story is good, but also a bit confusing. Lots of time travel and unforseen consequences
    [*] Hidden "super" bosses
    [*] You can go back to previous chapters whenever you are not in currently in the middle of a new chapter, you won't "miss" items or interactions. Some items require you to go back later after obtaining items/skills, but this is mostly just for completionism

The cons

  [*] The exessive hitstop the game uses actually causes lag in some boss fights. Also if you do not like hitstop, give the demo a go before purchasing it
  [*] The arena...my god this thing can be annoying. Every time you fail you have to go through loading screens, talk to a guy, select the mission you'd like to try again, another loading screen..

I honestly did not realize what I was getting into when I got this. It's been a ride which ate into my daily schedules and left me a sleepless wreck at work for a week and I do not regret this one bit. It's been a ride, and a magnificent one at that.

Gameplay is a 2D side scrolling brawler, with JRPG-style progression. The whole feel of it feels nostalgic and made me think of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, which I really think the developer drew a lot of inspirations from. The best thing about gearing up and character progression is that the whole thing feels super rewarding... It actually made grinding fun for me because it's always very exciting to see what comes next beyond the mountain of grind.

Understanding that the base of the game is actually a solo development freeware game made me overlook the animation janks and bugs that came along with it. Over the course of these few days, I've seen the developer putting out multiple patches for bug fixes, translation improvement and etc. Coming from games where developers just left the errors and bugs as is (cough, NIS), made me appreciate Astlibra's developer way more. A dragon sank through the ground one time and killing a God got me stuck in a timeless prison of the arena where I couldn't do anything or progress in another time, but seeing how proactive the developer is, I'm sure the game will be in a much, much more polished state when I'm back for round 2 to get the few remaining achievements.

Music is generally great BUT the occasional gratuitous English rap tracks do keep me on my toes. I shouldn't discuss this here because this review can very well turn into a thesis submission by the time I'm done.

Bottom Line: This game invoked such a nostalgic feel in me even when I've never even heard about Astlibra or the developer KEIZO until 5 days ago. Initially I got the game for the gameplay but the story hit me like a truck and I'm stuck on the ride in front of the windshield. I love this game so much like you wouldn't believe.

After all that good stuff, the game leaves me wanting more. Like seriously, the game came out of nowhere and showed me its potential, leaving me slightly depressed knowing that if there's a sequel or any other project of this magnitude from the developer, it'll probably be a year to a few years away.

I just hope it ain't 14 years away.

Walked in blind and was pleasantly surprised at how crisp the gameplay feels. You have quite a bit of reign on how you want to build your character, and you're not severely penalized for completely neglecting certain stats. I'm playing on hard and it's just about how I expected it to feel: a decent challenge where you get punished for mistakes, but not to the point where you're one-shot by a random slime. I do have some frustrating times where I get hit-stunned and die, but that's because I did something stupid. Thankfully, the skip event system is actually pretty good.

123781705.review:
"The fruit of 15 years of development and love."

I'm not a big fan of 2D sidescrollers. While I appreciate the genre, for some reason, games like Hollow Knight or Dust tend to bore me after a few hours. The only other 2D game of this type that I enjoyed till the end was Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, a game that, till the end, I felt I really didn't want to end. Astlibra was the same for me.

There is much I could say about the very interesting progression mechanics, the fun and challenging combat on higher difficulties, and the unique and interesting art style that fits the game perfectly. Above all, I'd like to compliment the story. While the twists and revelations of many stories across all media became predictable to me after many years, Astlebra kept me guessing until the end. I don't want to spoil anything, so I will keep it short and simple. The characters are great, the backstory is well developed and introduced at a great pace for the player, and the twists and turns are surprising but not in an unbearable way with the related elements of the story already introduced. There are also many side details that you can piece together from clues found around the world through exploration.

It's not really a complaint; it doesn't bother me, but I know there are people who are bothered by some innuendos and sexualization. I wouldn't say there is a lot of it in the game, and for me, it was in no way a distraction from the story, but it is there. Some of it could be said to fit with the themes of the story, as gods and goddesses of old religions were heavily sexualized. (I think there could be a big debate about what sexual stuff is natural for us since we are beings born of desire, but well, I don't think review is the place for this.) Aside from that, I think it could do without, but it does help to develop the characters' relationship in some ways. Anyway, just be mindful of it if it's something that bothers you.

Well? What are you waiting for? Go and experience this unique game!

✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨✨[quote] 10/10 Side-scrolling Cats recommend this game.

☑️Reasonable price tag.
☑️Delivers a unique RPG experience.
☑️Great story.
☑️Great character personalities.
☑️Great music / boss music.
☑️Addicting as hell combat.
☑️Menu sound effects are great.
☑️Incentive to farm mats for new weapons.
☑️A system to grow your character.
☑️Build the way you want.
☑️Weapons respond well to their WEIGHT.

❌A few minor translation errors. 
❌Boss HP scaling is absurd. 

Astlibra is a unique experience. 

I went in expecting the game to be mediocre due to the trailers showing overly complex designs for the characters and back grounds. But putting that aside, I decided to give it a honest try.

It felt like I was a kid again as silly as that sounds, playing games like Maplestory, running around mindlessly mowing down hoards of monsters for the sake of wanting to level up and farm materials for quests / weapon crafting. The story is pretty predictable, as in if you know something the characters do not you have to force them to do what you know you shouldn't, if that makes sense. 

The story is good regardless, but the desire to want to actually go out and farm materials from monsters and minerals is just as good. I spent 2 hours in the demo area alone just unlocking everything and having fun and another 4+ hours in the lava cave, once again farming. 

The proficiency system as well gives you a lot of reason to want to keep mowing down enemy after enemy along with the very fair growth system which is kind of similar to Final Fantasy XII with it's "Zodiac" system. Granting you new skills and bonuses in your overall character stats at the cost of grains from your enemies. If you can't afford lets say 5 green, you can use 15 of another colour to grow without having to search for those specific types of monster drops. 

The issue with Boss HP scaling comes with the difficulty setting. Monsters will gain a lot more damage to you, while also having a lot more health. Easy mode has most bosses and the very first boss you encounter at level 7-9 (unless you power farm) with about 9k health which takes forever, but it's fine cause you take like no damage, however, the harder boss fights have over 20k while being able to one shot you if you haven't been power-leveling or doing proper hit and run tactics.

[h1]My personal opinion?[/h1]
I rarely get this attached to video games, the last time I was this invested in a story was when I was playing through Divinity Original Sin II. Lost in thought and the world I was exploring. 

Try the Demo. 

It's very short and doesn't offer to much, but it will at the very least help you understand what the game is all about. 

It can be a little bit confusing at first, but it's honestly really fun. The combat isn't perfect, but it's a Hack & Slash! Run in, mow down enemies and bosses, farm the materials and get some new gear, unlock new skills and weapons to take on bigger foes and challenges. 

The game was developed by a solo Japanese developer for over 14 years. KEIZO has a daily job and only worked on the game after he got back home. You know it's not easily to develop a video game on your own especially over 14 years of development. However, with the help of prolific artist Shigatake (Dragon’s Crown) and Haku Tatsufuchi (Magic: The Gathering), and Publisher WhisperGames, the game has got a "Revision" upgrade, which you see here today. 

Stay and pay attention to the story, it might have it's translation errors here and there, but outside of that, it's pretty solid. It definitely makes me want to play it, not for any other reason than it's good and nostalgic.

EDIT:

It keeps getting BETTER and BETTER the more I play this game. The time travel, the plot, the story, the characters. My god.
